thread.text:
Has anyone rooted their Mate 9? Applied any ROMs? If so, what's been your experience? Was it worth it? 
I recently got the Oreo update and it's very very very nice. No problems whatsoever and the battery life continues to be ridiculously good.
I just wondered if there were any compelling reasons to consider rooting/ROMing the Mate 9 to make it even better.

From a general Android POV, the only compelling reason to root or flash a custom ROM is to be able to enjoy your phone for a longer period. OEMs in general tend to drop phone support really fast, and a custom ROM is the only way to bypass that.

title: USB disconnects when screen is off

replies.text: Hmm. I think I may have found my solution. I updated to Oreo and reset my phone. Huawei has some pretty harsh power saving stuff going on. title: Huawei Mate 9 Has Become My Favorite Phone

thread.text:
I’m always curious about Android phones other than Samsung and I wanted to see what all the “Huawei Hype” was about. I purchased a Mate 9 and started using it as my daily driver. Much to my surprise, I preferred the Mate 9 to my Samsung Note 8. I’m going to turn 79 this year and both my vision and hearing are feeling their age. The Mate 9’s display, a 16:9 LCD screen with 1080p resolution, was easier on my eyes and the speaker seemed louder. I could have lowered the resolution on my Note 8 and increased the size of the icons and text, but it didn’t seem to make much sense to “dumb down” Samsung’s flagship smartphone. Also, I found that I wasn’t using some of the features on the Note 8, such as the S-pen. I decided to sell my Note 8 and keep the Mate 9.
So far, I’m very happy with my choice of the Mate 9. It’s easy for me to hold, the screen is large and bright, and the sound is loud enough for me to hear. It seems just as fast and smooth as my Note 8, and it charges faster and a charge lasts longer. I think it’s an ideal phone for us older folks. I have only one minor complaint, and it’s one I have with other major smartphone companies; the lack of prompt software updates. My Mate 9 is still running Android 7 (Nougat) and the security updates are not current. I spoke with Huawei tech support and was told that new software has been released but the updates are pushed in batches and it might take a couple of months for the new software to be pushed to my phone.

Glad you are loving the mate 9, I purchased mine February last year best decision I ever made, it's a great device hugely underrated, I also now picked up the Mate 10 Pro it's a more refined than the Mate 9, it's just beautiful.

It is a really good phone.
Had mine almost 10 months now.
I just got mine last week. It’s a nice phone. Nice Big phone.
i like Huawei's software, seems like they took LG and Samsung and mashed it together and took the best stuff

replies.text: I like it fine too yet it’s one of the things reviewers seem to get caught up on. I honestly don’t see the problem, I like it fine.

thread.text: Reviewers are subjective and bash it because if that which is why I always take their review's as such. Even battery Life or camera reviews on smartphone are subjective. I love my mate 9 coming up to one year now since I first got it

Honestly it's the best phone after the mate 10 pro, and it doesn't cost much

I personally really like EMUI having experienced it on my Honor 8 that I sold a few months back (bad decision). But I'm back in the game. I traded for a Mate 9 the other day and waiting for it to arrive. Happy to hear most opinions on this thread are positive!

Been using my Mate 9 for 3 weeks now. It's an awesome phone. Sold my LG G6 (loved that phone) because I wanted a all metal build and a longer batter life. Like many Huawei fans, I enjoy EMUI. It's the fastest finger print scanner I've ever used. And the phone is so fast and smooth, it feels like a Snapdragon 835 chip. I'm a big fan of the Kirin chips (maybe better than Snapdragon?).
I have a Mate 10 and find myself using my Mate 9 still, just something about this phone that I miss when I'm not using it.

I just got mine today. Man...why have I not been on this phone earlier? It's actually a bit lighter and smaller than I expected, which is a welcome surprise. The phone also has a good presentation as I traded from a good user here on AC who had all the original packing. Every OEM should make their phones come with a little case and screen holder even if there are better things on the market. I really like that about Huawei. Only a few hours but I'm hooked.

I bought mine on ebay for $285 with some scuff and one small dent on it. There are much better ones for around $300. After testing I bought 2 more brand new ones for the $399 deal on Amazon that repeats itself every now and then.
Love the phone!!! Updated manually to Oreo and still good. Apart from the battery and awesome camera etc. I find that the screen is much better on my eyes compared to an Amoled screen. Especially at night when the the lights are out whenever I look at my old phones Amoled I feel more strain compared to the Mate 9. Plus it is so bright I can only use 30% brightness indoors and around 70-80% in direct sunlight.
I believe it would be much more common if it weren't for Korean lobbying. A few congressmen speaking out against the brand... paid lobbyists most probably...
I got mine recently and it's a nice device with lots of spice. The battery life is very good. I also have two iPhone Xes and the Mate 9 is great when I feel like using something different.

title: For UK Owners - Barclays Apps Not Working?

thread.text:
Phone is brand new, not rooted. Installed the Barclays, Barclays Pingit and Barclaycard apps on it today and tried to run them and they all just quit straight back to the desktop, don't even get as far as the login screen. 
There's no problem with the servers because I can still log in with the same apps on my old Samsung S7 (running Nougat) phone. I've got apps for American Express and Tesco Bank that work perfectly so it looks like it's some sort of Barclays/Huawei compatibility thing. :-( :-(
Anyone else come across this, and more importantly, fixed it?
Thanks for reading!

Hi, 
I've got the Porsche design mate 9 and I'm struggling with the Barclays Apps too...
It seems that there was an update in the last day or so according to some reviews who were struggling but I haven't been updated as yet

I contacted Barclays and got this response... their broken English not mine by the way! Seems like they are aware of the issue but their reply doesn't inspire me with a great deal of confidence given they mention Samsung as having the issue after I'd already told them it worked fine on my old S7...

Just in case anyone else is looking for some info I thought I'd update this thread with the latest situation.
Unfortunately it's not good news - a very poor show from Barclays - this STILL isn't working. I've complained again (lost count how many times I've done so now) - here's the latest response from them TODAY:
"Thank you for your message regarding your mobile banking app. I hope you are well and enjoying your day. 
I have checked into this for you and I can confirm that we are aware of problems incurred with the Huawei 9 when downloading the mobile banking app. 
I can totally appreciate the inconvenience this is causing to you however rest assured this is under urgent investigation but at present I would not be able to advise of a timescale of when this will be fixed for you. Our team are working as fast as possible to have this resolved. "

title: Found a fast charging power bank (battery) at a low cost for the Mate 9

thread.text:
This is it. After reading and searching, I found a low priced power bank that does fast charging on the Mate 9. I bought it. I tried it. I'm taking it across the world this month.Tronsmart Presto 10000mAh Ultra-Compact Portable External Battery Power Bank Battery Pack With Huawei FCP Fast Charging Technologyhttps://www.amazon.com/Tronsmart-100...cUvbUpU5835870
That's as big as it get but with some airlines, like BA, lowering their maximum allowed size down to 20,000 mHa, this will work.
If it fails, I'll be sure to come back and post that.

replies.text: OMG thank you for finding this!

thread.text:
In the Q&A was mentioned by seller that is not compatible with Mate 9. 
You want the older, but has usb-c, 10400:https://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B01KN...cUvbUpU5837044

That was me who asked. Then, as I continued to search for a product, I saw this video where a guy who appears to work for Tronsmart explained and demonstrated. So - I ordered - it works. I am kind of in a desperate situation given the type of travel I'm going to be doing.
Oops, see that yours has USBC and Huawei phone.
One thing I didn't know or just didn't understand is that it appears I can fast charge using a cable with USB-A on one end and USB-C into your phone. I always thought it had to be C on both ends.
One might also try the best portable charger which is compatible not only with your Mate 9 but also with other devices.
This is awesome. Thank you.

Back from my latest trip - Africa. This battery provided my Mate with two solid, fast charges from about 20%. I also had to charge a camera battery once and it handled that. Basically, you can trust it will give you two but probably go even further.
Biggest drawback I found is, ironically, it's slow to recharge. Quick to charge, slow to recharge.
I emailed the company and suggested they make a larger one.FYI - I have sold my Mate 9 and moved on. I miss the lightning fast fingerprint reader. This battery also supports QC3 so I'll still use it.

replies.text: Funny story, I sold by mate 9 in Feb only to pick it up again in May haha. I also missed it.
For curiosity, did you drop it for which phone? Are you satisfied?
Thanks for the update! That's great to hear that it charged the phone quickly and reliably. What phone did you get as a replacement?

Galaxy S8+
Nothing wrong with the Mate. I'm just a phone nerd and decided I needed to try out a mainstream phone again. Had 6P then the Mate. Previously an LG. Haven't had a Samsung in a long time. Got the Best Buy $200 gift card on unlocked. Sold the gift card, lost $14.
Galaxy is what everyone says - an amazing phone. Shockingly gorgeous screen. If I had to be picky, I would say I like that I have AMOLED back since I am big on pure black themes. I also appreciate that it's encrypted since I travel internationally (maybe a little paranoid). I actually like the atpical format - the long form factor makes it really easy to hold. Having the standard Quick Charge makes it a LOT easier and cheaper to find adapters.
And.... wireless charging. Wow. Almost life changing. I bought a few plates and stuck them around.
Don't toss your Mate. It's still a really good phone. Screen is great if you don't have it sitting next to an AMOLED. Camera is amazing. And, like I said, that fingerprint reader is outstanding.

thread.text:
Just thought I'd share a screen shot of Ampere while plugged into that Tronsmart Power pack that @PaulQ found.
It does indeed support Mate 9 SuperCharge speeds (Over 4 volts and 3000Ma). It also fast charges my G6 and my brother's S8.

Huawei Super/Fast Charge
Qualcomm QC 3.0
Samsung Rapid Charge
Will test my friends Pixel soon for Google Power Deliver as well.

title: why can't change wallpaper in Settings from t white on my Mate 9?

thread.text: The wallpaper on my Mate 9 home and lock screen is black,but there is no way I can find to change it from that ugly white to some/black as well/ other color

Are you talking about the wallpaper on the homescreen, or the background of the all of the settings menus?
To change wallpaper, you typically have to long-press an empty part of the homescreen, then select the Wallpaper option. You should be able to select from a wide range of static or live wallpapers there.
I mean the background of the settings menu

The settings menu wallpaper cannot be changed on any device. This only changes if the phone supports a theme engine like Samsung, Sony, or LG does with their devices. Other options are using a third party theme engine like substratum, but I find that too much hassle.
thanks,I have suspected it.I have a LG V20 and could do it on that,looks much better.But I thought I have seen one Mate 9,some reviewer on YouTube had it set up like that.

I just bought a Mate 9 and overall, I love this phone.
There is one issue that is making me crazy though and I can't figure out a solution for it.
I use Office365 for my email, calendar and contacts. The email syncs fine using MailWise (didn't like the stock email app) but the contacts and calendar are having sync issues.
I use Digi-Cal and when I enter a new appointment on my phone, it shows up in outlook on my PC in a weird color (not my stock calendar color).
The contacts all downloaded fine from Office365 but I can't edit any of them or create a new contact that saves to Office365.
Has anyone else had these sync issues and how did you resolve them?
Thanks.

I use Nine for my Exchange account and it works great, you could try that (there's a trial version I believe... but for me, totally worth the 9 bucks). The appointments on your calendar might be showing up as a separate Calendar (since they're being created by another app), which would explain why they show up in a different color. Check the Calendar app to see if it's creating it in a different calendar and if you can select the 'default' one from your Office account.

title: Lock screen - bypass swipe to get to home screen?

thread.text:
Folks,
I'm a long-time Samsung user, and I always have just completely disabled the whole lock screen nonsense -- I've usually had the flip covers that turn the screen on when you open them, and then I'm right at the home screen, with no swiping necessary. But I sure can't find any option like that on the new Mate 9 I just picked up -- is there any way to get rid of that infernal need to swipe every dang time you want to turn the screen on??
Thanks for your help!
Fingerprint id on the back is fast reliable and easy habit.
Fingerprint
No, a thousand times no, a million times no, a trillion times no -- I just want to turn my phone on and use it -- is that really too much to ask??

You don't even need to tap or press power button. Not.One.Extra.Step. 
Grab and you almost can't miss, unlike other phones.
It doesn't have the always on when being looked at which to me is much more if pet peeves. 
Play with for few days. Suspend judgement. 
If it is a No I don't think fingerprint Id is secure, that's another matter. Six character pin or greater will be needed and FID is very convenient to access and act as password.

No, whatever it is, I don't want to screw around with it. No, I'm not going to come back in here and go, "Now the fingerprint ID thing doesn't work, and I can't get into my phone," like I've seen a thousand different times with other phones. No, I'm not going to have my phone just sitting on a table, and whereas I could just open up the cover and go right in with every Samsung phone I've ever used, now I've got to pick up the phone, press the fingerprint ID thing, hope that the aftermarket case that I'll put on it might still work with the fingerprint ID, then open up the case. And so on. I have such a third-party case coming from Amazon -- a flip-open case with a window, very much like the Samsung S-View cases, and it allegedly works with the Mate 9 very similar to how Samsung works with their cases.
And make no mistake: If I can't just open up that cover and see the home screen without further swiping or grabbing or putting my finger somewhere, I'll put a fork in it. And I'll return the Mate 9. I just AM NOT going to screw around with just turning on my dang phone dozens and dozens of times every day. I've never had a password on any computer I've ever owned, I've never had a password on any notebook computer I've ever owned, I've never had any phone that I've had to screw around with swiping or using a fingerprint ID, I've never had any tablet that I've had to screw around with swiping or using a fingerprint ID, and I sure as heck am not going to start screwing around with something like this every time I look at my phone.
Yes -- gasp -- I'll be totally unprotected, but that's how I've been since Day 1, and I'm not going to start putting up with computers or whatever that put blocks in my way when I want to use them. I can see being all passworded up with "work" devices, but this is a deal-breaker for me if I can't just open the cover of this new case I'm getting, and then the Mate 9 will just show me the home screen, without some other interaction from me. Yes, it's that big of a deal to me, and I presume all of the "use the fingerprint ID" replies mean that yes, indeed, there is no way to just turn the phone on and be at the home screen. I'll give it one more chance, when the case gets here, but at this point I'm 99% ready to return the Mate 9.
You need another Samsung. Hope it doesn't explode.

Jeez. Just go back to Samsung. I hope they don't change that feature inn your case.
If you aren't willing to spend time with a new device to see if you develop the unconscious movements necessary to operate that new device, you shouldn't be switching devices. That extra swipe could become such a habit that you don't even notice it.
If you compare this Mate with the Nexus 6P (my previous phone), the Mate has its power and volume buttons reversed. I kept hitting volume up instead of the power button. Instead of complaining, I gave it time and guess what happened,... I retrained myself and now I go right for the power button.
I have to agree that I have mixed feelings about the fingerprint sensor on the back. It's so fast though. I get that some people may not like it. Bit - Samsung appears to be moving theirs to the back too.
If a phone from a different manufacturer doesn't do what you want, stick with the manufacturer you like.

Hi All, I just solved the issue on my mate 9.

so, this just worked on my Mate 9, before i give what "fixed" my issue, I will give you want customer service gave me since this might also work. 
Thanks so much for writing, and sorry to hear you’re having issues listening.
Let’s try the following steps to troubleshoot the app (not to worry, your Pandora account and stations won’t be affected):
1. Update the app to ensure you are on the latest version of Pandora.
2. If you have a battery saver or task manager app, make exceptions for Pandora or try turning it off completely.
3. Clear data for Pandora in your phone’s settings.
4. Make sure the app is installed to the phone’s local memory.
5. Lower your audio quality in the Settings menu. To get to your Settings, open your Pandora app to the Station list, tap the menu icon, and select Settings.
-If you’re a Pandora Premium subscriber, select Audio Quality & Download.
-If you’re not a Pandora Premium subscriber, select Advanced and then uncheck Higher Quality Audio.
Then, try Pandora again. If the issue continues, please proceed with the following steps:
6. Uninstall and reinstall the app.
- From the home screen, tap on the menu or App Drawer, select Settings, and open your Applications folder (sometimes located under Device).
- Go to the Application Manager, scroll down and select Pandora, then Uninstall.
- Once that’s done, reinstall the app through the Google Play Store or Amazon Appstore. Finally, launch the Pandora app and sign in.
Keep in mind that the steps to find certain settings on Androids can be different depending on the type of Android phone you have, as well as what Android OS you are running.
If you’re having trouble completing these steps, try contacting your device’s manufacturer for further help navigating their operating system.
Let me know how it goes.

The GKK case I returned was easy-peasy:Go to my orderTap return itemGive reasonChoose return and refund methodPrint return labelRepack then apply labelRide bicycle to UPS dropbox and dropReturn to house and continue drinking coffee Lol...
Takes about 45 minutes or less for small items.
When UPS scans returned item Amazon applies my refund amount.
With Amazon, on a number of occasions, Amazon just refunded me and let me keep the item... Especially on low priced items.
I'm the same with both. If I buy something pretty cheap from either site. I wouldn't waste my time returning it
I would return it just for the principle.
Would you do it even if the items cost $2-4
Sure, I have returned items even less than that.
Eh too much work to return such a cheap item. But everyone is different.
I use the term return loosely. When they are really cheap, Amazon just credits me for the purchase and they just tell me to throw it out.
Thats a great reason then. Thought you'll put the effort into packaging it and drive to UPS to ship it back. That would be alot of work for couple of bucks back
But what I am saying is that amazon usually refunds without the requirement to return the item, on cheap items. So no need to go to ups.
I get that part. Its much convenient that way. Although people could just lie about the quality to get refunds and still keep the item

Yes you can, although that would be unethical. And in some cases amazon has asked for pics. Also, if they think that you are defrauding them then they will ban your account and there's no way to get it reinstated.

Nice, good that they asked for pictures. 
Not falling for people cheap scams to get free items.
Yeah amazon has good customer service but they also have a very harsh auditing team to find fraud and other things

thank you

I don't know for sure, but I'm guessing that drafts get saved as cached data. So a system update would probably clear the cache. I wouldn't have thought that a reboot would clear the cache, but maybe it does for certain apps.
thanks. guess that must be it.. sucks though

I'm currently using an HTC 10 but I've been thinking about the I don't know if it's an upgrade or side grade buying the mate 9... has anyone gone from the htc10 to the m9 and how is the external speaker comparable and the headphone?
If anybody switch from the 10 to the 9 and you can share some of their thoughts that would be great that would help me decide whether I should or not thanks.

Hey bro, this was my path exactly although I went from htc 10 to mate 9 pro rather than normal mate 9.
It all comes down to how often you listen to headphones, as the headphones output (loudness, bass delivery, power) is definitely not in the same ballpark as the 10. Having said that, it's decent sound but nothing to brag about. The speaker set up on the mate however is very similar in function and quality (maybe even a tad better). Lastly on sound, I find the Bluetooth sound output is also a bit lacking but that could just be a placebo affect from the difference in headphone sound. 
Having said that, everything else is an upgrade: battery life, the screen on the pro is better, camera, speed of the device granted the 10 is no slouch either, software is ugly and needs a launcher/icon pack lol but software functionality is on point for the most part--emui5 finally adds to the Android experience rather than takes away. But yeah, despite the headphone sound it is an upgrade in every other way in my opinion. The only think I'm stuck on is trying to figure out how to get Spotify on the lockscreen while music is playing. It can be done via app but I'm trying to figure it out natively 🤔 Feel free to ask any questions though bro!

Hey... Thanks so much for taking the time to write your experience... I kind of figured/guessed it was upgrade in every area but maybe not the audio... Thanks for confirming my thoughts on that. Audio quality is important to me, but I got to say the screen/battery life/camera is looking pretty nice on the Mate 9.. So why did you get the pro? Because the screen has a higher resolution or the smaller form factor? OK maybe I need to check out the pro?

To be honest, I have small hands so I went for the smaller form factor... The screen weighed into it a little bit, but for the same price as the normal mate, I got the pro 128gb 6gb ram... It just made sense! The normal made was a tad bit on the large side but I would have been happy with it if the pro wasn't an option
I found myself in the exact same predicament. I don't have either phone but I am trying to choose between the two. Which one has the better camera?

thread.text:
So after some assistance with some helpful people, I got the B302 Android 8.0 installed on my Mate 9 C567 US variant. It's only been an hour so I am still playing with it. I will say this, its very nice. Keep in mind it's a Beta, so some things are quirky and some thing are missing/incorrect. That being said, here is what I have noticed so far:
1. Do not ask me about battery life, it's only been an hour, I will say your battery life will probably be what it is now.
2. The settings are as they show in the Android 8.0 screen shots and how they show in the Mate 10 videos. Yo have to dig around a bit as things are more condensed and there not as obvious as the once were. No big deal, but it took a minute to find some things.
Also there is a display setting that is new as well. You can switch from HD (1280x720), FHD (1920x1080, or Smart, this will automatically lower screen resolution to save on battery.
3. The System information is incorrect at this point. Here is what I see:
A. Device name is Honor 8
B. Model shows as M300-L29
C. EMUI version shows as 5.0.1 (so I don't know if its 8.0 or not, someone help me out on this)
D. MEID is all 0's
E. RAM shows as 2 GB
F. Internal storage shows as 11GB free and 16 GB total 
G.Security patch is September 5th
H, And for those that care the base band is 20.201.44.19.845,20.201.44.19.845
Again this is a Beta, so things may not seem right. I can tell you my storage is fine, and my RAM is as well.
Other things I have noticed, no option to reconfigure the soft key's, they are fixed in the stock position. Also no option to hide the soft key at this time. Install unknown apps has no toggle to enable you have to enable each app. No new wallpapers or sounds as of yet. The camera is slightly different as well. The top has different icons and there is a 3D Panorama added that was a 3rd party proior. I will attach a screen shot of this at the bottom.
There is a new feature that I thought was cool, it a private screen. It's like a user space that you can have a different setup for. So it's secured and has to be used with default storage set to internal, it won't work on an SD card. 
I can say as I am restoring my data, it is noticeably snappier (placebo possibly) but it certainly does appear to be faster and less hesitation opening apps or switching back through resents.
So that's all I have for now. I will update later once I get some time in with it. I want to look at Bluetooth function to see if its better/updated.
So there it is, this is going to be a great build once it's put of Beta. With any luck it will be available soon and a bit more polished as well. Stay hopeful and keep an eye out for the final release, it's going to be worth it.https://drive.google.com/file/d/0Bx9HKaADOzCwX1IwYkNVMHR0T00/view?usp=sharing
The icons in order are: Flash, Wide Aperature, Beauty, Moving Picture (its like a GIF or short video), and the rest are the same#Update #
It turns out you can configure the soft keys, hide them and enable the floating nav button. Turns out it's in the smart assistance setting. It's a very cool feature. Much easier to use than fling or any third party app I have used.
Also just like Beta B230 Android Pay is broken. It should be fixed with a stable release
#Update# 1:33pm
Picture in Picture works great and it's pretty awesome. Limited amount of apps at this time but still...
10/21 #Uodate #
Home button is animated like the Google devices (color dots)
#Update# 10/25/17
I have experienced some of the settings crashing when attempting to access them. Manly some of the batter optimization settings. To combat this, if you use the search field in the settings you can access them without failure. Also, some apps, Instagram in particular, will randomly close out while using. Additional, I have certain apps set as administrator, occasional, these apps become disabled as the admin.

thread.text: How is it so far ?

So far it's a home run. Very soild and stable. Battery life is improved, there are two new 3D lock screen wallpapers that move as you move the device, it is more fluid, snappier and faster. So far the only bug I noticed is the Bluetooth was chippie randomly when using headphones whith the device in my back pocket, move to the front and problem solved. Other than that it's definitely a daily driver. 
The obvious is that one of EMUI 8 features are not available on this device, the built in Microsoft translator in the camera as this is for the AI chip.
Here is the Change Log directly from Huawei:
This update to EMUI is based on the Android 8.0 operating system. Featuring enhanced performance and security, EMUI 8.0 delivers a fresh experience that lets you get more out of your device. We highly recommend updating now.
</feature>
<feature>Recommended level: ★★★★★</feature>
</features>
<features module="[Highlights]">
<feature>
● Smarter A new floating Navigation dock lets you perform frequently-used operations from anywhere on the screen. Newly added home screen shortcuts let you quickly access the app features you use most frequently. Simply touch and hold an app icon to display a shortcut menu. ● Faster AI-based optimizations deliver greater stability, fluidity, and speed. The system boots faster, videos are more fluid, and images thumbnails load rapidly even in huge volumes. ● Safer Enjoy enhanced protection for your system, privacy, and data with new updates to system security and PrivateSpace. ● Cooler Take sweeping 3D panoramas, set 3D dynamic lock screen wallpapers, and discover new possibilities with a host of new features and settings. Use Portrait mode to effortlessly capture glossy, celebrity-worthy portrait shots with stylish bokeh effects.
</feature>
</features>
<features module="[Find out more]">
<feature>
● Improved false touch protection functionality reduces unintended operations on the touch screen in a wider range of scenarios. ● Smart tips recommend you faster and smarter ways to operate your phone, appearing in specific usage scenarios and responding to your usage habits. ● The PrivateSpace menu has been optimized, making it easier to create a PrivateSpace on your device. Files can now be moved between the MainSpace and PrivateSpace with ease. ● Contacts and Email now let you sync the career details of your LinkedIn contacts. ● Settings has been redesigned for clearer and more intuitive organization. ● Gallery now features a recycle bin that retains deleted photos for up to 30 days. Accidentally deleted photos can be restored with a single touch. ● Phone Manager has been simplified to make managing your device easier. Standard cleanups are faster and deep cleanups more thorough. ● Your device can now connect to two different Bluetooth devices at the same time, such as a band and a car.

I'm in a similar situation, considering to buy a Mate 9 on the "trailing edge" when it's not that expensive any more. I did something similar in September 2004 when I signed up for a Samsung Note 3 with a respectable telco. By that time, this model was almost a year old, so I got it cheap. 
Trouble is, the camera on that Note 3 wasn't anywhere near the hyped-up quality of the reviewers. My wife's S4, even older than my phone, was making better photos.
I seriously suspect that manufacturers, in collusion with the telco, are putting on the market phones with inferior components, when the model is approaching the end of its lifecycle. After all, who would publish a review of a one-year old model ? 
Sounds dirty, but makes sense, and they can get away with it, given the focus on new models.

The SE is a really good phone, especially the compact size! The Mate 9 would be a bit of a jump as far as getting used to the larger screen size, etc; but EMUI is a great OS experience! It's really unlike any Android OS experience I've had thus far. There's even an EMUI Theme Store app that allows you to download iOS themes for your phone!
All that being said, the Mate 9 is a fantastic phablet experience with a fantastic camera and good OS backing. Go for it! You can always keep your SE as a backup.

replies.text: Textra does this very nicely. From the main screen, select the menu button (3 dots) on the upper right, then select SETTINGS, then CUSTOMIZE NOTIFICATIONS, then REPEAT NOTIFICATIONS. I discovered that the notification interval is every 2 minutes in Textra. There have apparently been a whole bunch of requests to be able to customize this time interval.

title: Huawei - do they care at all about recent security threats?

thread.text:
1.) Blueborne - very serious exploit that shouldn't remain unpatched for long.
2.) Bootloader flaws - Huawei singled out by USC and ZDNet as having the most serious vulnerability. https://www.google.com/amp/www.zdnet...idia-chipsets/
Based on knowledge of this company do we think they'll do anything in a reasonable timeframe? I asked about Blueborne at least on their Facebook page and just got a big dodge.

This study involves the use of current technology to exploit vulnerabilities in the P8, which was released over 2 years ago with Android 5 (Lollipop). It requires the attacker have physical access to and full control of the device. There were no cited identified known instances of these vulnerabilities being used in the wild. 
Bootloader security has improved significantly on 2016 and 2017 devices RUNNING Android 6, 7, and now 8.
"no body cares" the september security patches won't be delivered to all devices.
It's frustrating, I don't want to run Bluetooth on my phone till they release the September patch but who know when that's going to be.

well in this case, the September security patch protects against Blueborne

title: Just made the Switch from a V10 to the Mate 9!

what's your opinion about the camera?
How's the performance compare to the rest
So far the battery life is miles better than my V10. Performance is up there too. I don't really see any real difference in terms of speed. Plus I enjoy the 16:9 aspect ratio still.
How did you like the EMUI vs LG skin

EMUI is very different from LG's skin, but refreshing. I enjoy the mix of organic and tron inspired styles. I will say that I miss the theming options under Nougat on my V10. Also the location of some settings in EMUI is a bit scattered. However despite the differences between the two, I enjoy both in different ways.

thread.text: I wonder if our ignoring call quality and sound has cost us...these companies that produce smartphones have terrific tech engineering labs working hard on making the tech even better at everything it does...constant improvement seems to be the modus operandi these days with all tech...not talking about it, not complaining when perhaps we should has likely caused those engineers to completely ignore advancing that part of the technology...where could we be if they strove to improve the sound those tinny little speakers make?...there are home speaker drivers that attach to large panes of glass in windows to turn the entire pane into a speaker...reverse that and it becomes a microphone, sort of...the point is...has our silence on the topic lost us the chance for great improvements and new technology fronts for sound from small sources like phones and tablets?...i'd love to speak with an engineer at samsung or any other device maker about the potential for advancing sound qaulity...and there's a second point...why not add DAC to these smart devices?...make a real audifiles dream device?...something that sounds good alone but when connected to a home speaker system sounds freaking AMAZING...there are quite a few companies out there that would love to collaberate and license their name and products to go along with these phones, tablets, and laptops...and some do, i've seen B&O, Harmon Kardon, Beats, before on devices, in fact, i still own an old HTC smartphone with Beats sound enhancment and use it just as an MP3 player...because the sound when connected to my home system is absolutely Fantastic!...Do any of you know of a new or new-ish smartphone with the Beats sound enhancment???...i'd buy that right now...this instant...credit card in hand.

thread.text:
There is not a lot of discussion about the Mate 9's excellent radios and reception.
Reviewers probably are in max reception areas. Test the phone where there is dodgy reception, which ones hang onto a signal? Weak signal is one of the worst battery killers.

I've used my Mate 9 in a number of weaker 2G only locations here in California and Nevada.
Voice calls were fine with few low signal drops.
I must say my network carrier coverage has improved immensely over the past 2 years.
Have no fear...the Huawei Mate 9 handles voice very well in my opinion as an actual user.

I don't think I've enjoyed any phone as much as the Mate 9. In the last few years I've had an HTC One, a couple Moto X's, a Nexus 6, and a Moto G4+ (I was really on a Motorola kick for a while). I just can't get over how impressed I am with the Mate. Always getting 8+ hours of SOT and never having to worry about charging during the day? Absolutely addictive. Dual cam with an insane amount of control in the camera app? Yes please. A SOC that can chew through anything? Yep. Stupid fast charging? Got it. 
The only thing I really miss these days are the killer blacks that AMOLED can provide.

With the camera do you guys stick to 20mp resolution with no zoom or the 12mp resolution to take advantage of the Hybrid Zoom? And do you notice much of a difference between the two?
On my P10 I tend to stick to 20mp just to try get the best detail possible but I still struggle to see much difference between the two
I switch back and forth then often forget which shooting option I'm in. Seems to me like detail is about the same with saved pics.
20MP might have slightly more detail but i'm not sure... anyway here is a reason i love the Mate 9 over any phone.

thread.text:
I love my Mate 9, definitely the best I've had. 
What would I like to see in Mate 10? 
IP68 waterproofing, user replaceable battery of the same size, lower brightness setting for nighttime, brighter for sunshine (though it is better than many). 
Camera: stabilisation - it is much harder to hold a phone steady than it is a camera. Better focus on close objects. Better low light capability. 
Scrap the Huawei dialer, contacts, messaging and calendar and only pre-install Android standards. By all means offer their own as alternatives, but I like the same on all my devices. 
What don't I want? 
Please don't go thin display. The current trend for 2:1 screens is dreadful. It is only useful for films, and this is a generic use device masquerading as a phone. Stay with 16:9 or go the other way to 16:10.

Keep in mind a removable battery of the same size would need to be significantly larger than a non removable one. 
With regards to 2:1, i really liked it for reading emails and websites... Gives me a little more length to read
Getting back Mate 10. Huawei pushing the device with at&t. I'm crossing my fingers for unlock US version.

title: Is call quality not a thing anymore?...How does the speakerphone sound on both ends of a call?...

thread.text:
Ok, so what, I'm 50 now and though screen quality and battery life are important, processor speed and memory is real too, sure a great camera would be fun...but no one speaks to call qaulity anymore, how does it sound? does the speakerphone on both ends of a phonecall sound great or does it sound like a wind tunnel or two cans and a string?...
I want to own this phone...but no one is reviewing phone call quality anymore...have we progressed so much it's great in every phone made now?...any help would be fantastic, and try not to be too hard on the old man...

"have we progressed so much it's great in every phone made now?"
I think yes!! that's it, we're in 2017 and stuff like this isn't a big problem.

Almost 65 here with 50% hearing loss in the right ear.
I have the Mate 9 and find voice call quality fine on the T-Mobile network.
Also never had any complaints from others I speak with.
The speakerphone is loud and clear for me also.
Title says it all. I turn it off, turn it on again, when logo appears I hold volume down button but my phone boots in normal mode... Is there another way to boot into safe mode?
Solved it! The problem was I pressed the button too soon. Needed to wait untill the animation logo begins. If pressed sooner it wouldn't work

I'm having trouble with my speakerphone. It works fine if I turn it on touching the screen while calling but that's not the problem. The problem is doing it without touching the phone. Tried doing it in different ways and always failed:
1. Tasker can't control my speakerphone. Tried automating a call so that was always on speakerphone ON, Didnt work. 
I know it's something wrong with the phone since all other Tasker automated profiles are working fine.
2. Another symptom: Wear speaker (which is an app for Android Wear that does exactly that - turning speaker ON automatically when answering a call) also doesn't work.
3. And another thing: Voice answering also doesn't work. Call rings, but neither "answer call" nor "reject call" voice command do a thing. At one time that DID work, but ONLY when phone wasn't in silent mode - when the call ringing was silent or on vibrate it would not work. So one day I let it ring on silent and enter quick toggles (while silently "ringing") and turned on sound hoping it would than accept voice commands( answer or reject), but I did exactly the opposite. Since than it doesn't work AT ALL (silent, vibrate or not).
Non rooted Huawei Mate 9. Emui 5.0. Anroid 7.0 
Hope I made myself clear. Any suggestions would be very much appreciated. Thanks
Huawei Mate Pro 9 one week old, but battery only last about 12-13 hours, anyone with better battery life
I use GSam Battery Monitor Pro to keep track of my battery stats. Based on the app, I was getting close to 8 hours of on screen and about 21 hours from 100% to 5%
Thanks. Just installed that, looks like this.. Phone feels a bit hot ? But maybe its just me?
Is that 5 minutes sot down to 80%? Unless there is a super aggressive app causing that it may be fault. Have you tried doing a factory data reset, or at least a cache wipe?
Yes... just went to the dealer, I get a new phone since this must be defective and only 1 week old. Hope the new one is better.

replies.text: So,the new model you received is feeling hot and is similar in terms of battery consumption? What apps are you using on it - social media, etc?
I have not yet had my replacement phone, but I will next week, its the "old phone", that is getting hot, so I am pretty sure something is wrong with it-
Oh, sorry, I misread - but I'm relieved it's the old phone that is still giving you trouble! Let us know how your new phone fares when it comes in!

thread.text: The phone also gets a bit hot

I had the same problem, it started a few days ago (the phone was great before).
I tried many ways, so many internet tutorials, and nothing worked.
I FOUND A SOLUTION! In a forum about the same problem on a nexus phone. It seems to be a problem about Android 7.0 (not the phone itself).
And the solution is: go to config - apps. Click on the three dots in right bottom. Click on "restore app preferences" or someting like that (My phone is in portuguese). Restart the phone.
Voilá! The phone come back to its great battery life!
Spread the information, please. I waste several days and finding no solution (and the solution was very, very simple).
Sorry for my bad english
Regards from Brazil!

replies.text:
Do you know what "restore app preferences" does? Did it set all of your apps back to default settings like when you installed them?
(and don't worry about your English, I am already impressed you know two languages!)

thread.text:
Well I'm pretty sure my first phone was defective, it got a bit hot to when using it. The new replacement phone has much better battery time.
Restoring app preferences, I guess this will also restore the battery firewall on Huawei phone, or at least, it will restore the settings pr app that will not allow the app to run in the background when the screen is off. If all apps are set to close when the screen is, you will get better battery life, but also you mite not get any notification settings, and some apps do need to run in the background. The Huawei battery firewall is a bit aggressive I think.
Cancel that. I just tried to do it and it pops up a notification of everything it's about to do when you do that reset.

I'm using my phone for a week, with all permissions set and it works just fine (discharge about 200-340mA).
It's a bug in Android 7.0 SO, it's happening with pixel phones too.
The phone is innocent!
I found the solution here:https://www.google.com.br/amp/s/amp....nougat_solved/
Other link with the same solution:https://www.google.com.br/url?sa=t&s...A5P8kXnN9E801w
Even in this forum it's happenning with LG phones after Nougat update:http://forums.androidcentral.com/lg-...gat-7-0-a.html

UPDATE: New OTA B175 update was released to LON-AL00.
Everything was fixed.
Battery discharging in 200-340 mAh, no more Android core apps draining battery, CPU in 533mHz most of tbe time.
Phone is superb now!

title: Disappointed with 5 hour on screen time battery life

thread.text:
I am a power user and have always valued battery life above all else. Been using the Moto Z Play which would average 8 hours OST. Chanced upon a free Mate 9 from my provider and switched to it, especially after I read that people were getting 8 to 9 hours or more OST. However, I have only got 5 hours average OST. I have already
* Reformatted
* Stopped using action launcher to reduce further drain and just using EMUI
* Turned off background data
* Auto kill apps when locked (tried to un kill also)
Basically tried a lot of battery tweaks. Except putting it in battery saver or ultra battery saver mode as it seems counter productive to have a phone that wont sync emails and direct messaging.
IS THIS NORMAL? Or did I get a lemon? Or are people bloating their OST's and posting them?
On the other hand, I have learned to appreciate the speed of the phone and the great screen size and mostly the great camera. I've just had to top up in the middle of the day. But ideally I would have liked to see those great battery life's everyone is talking about.

Sounds odd since even my 2 year old Note 4 battery (~3200mAh) can get me 4-5 hours SoT. I have battery saver turned on, but that's mostly for the screen. I still get notifications in Messenger, Gmail etc.

Everything that i have read would indicate that the Moto z play should get significantly more sot than the mate 9. In fact i was getting around 15-18 hours on my Moto Z Play. What i am getting at is if you get 8-9 on the z play then5 on the Mate 9 is about right. What other phones have you used and what sot where you getting on them
Use the Ultra Saving Mode to get yourself thru the day

replies.text: How much more SOT do you get on your mate 9 with ultra power saving mode on?
Quite a bit actually. 2-3 hrs more on SOT
That's pretty good, especially when you are not near a charger!

thread.text: Turn off Wi-Fi and perhaps Bluetooth if you need a lot of screen on time.

I've noticed the same issue on mine. What I've had to do is turn of LTE when I'm not using the phone. Searching for LATE seems to be the biggest drain on my phone by doing so I've added about 15 % to my battery life. I end my day with about 22% battery left

How old is device? I've been using mine for about 3 weeks so far and I get at times close to 7 hours of SOT I'm at 3-1/2 hours right now and at 45% I keep WiFi and Bluetooth on connected to my gear S3 sounds odd to me I got a 7 plus and this phone kicks that one's butt on SOT my LG V20 couldn't give me more than 4-1/2 maybe your provider can take it back and swap the device

My Mate 9 recently started seeing decreased battery life. Examining the power consumption of all the installed apps I determined the culprit was Google Photos. It was running constantly in the background. It would be the largest single power consumer - eating up as much as 40% of the battery. I tried everything. Force stopping the app would help, but was not a permanant solution. Deleted and re-installed the app didnt help. Finally discovered the problem was apparently a corrupt image file on my SD card. Downloaded all the photos in that directory and re-started with a clean photos directory. That did the trick! Back to normal. Google Photos app now only consuming 0.35% of my battery. I can easily get 7 hours of SOT now with a full day on the phone.

replies.text: Yeah a corrupt media file will really eat up battery life. For basic troubleshooting, you can remove the sd card to see if the provl persists.

thread.text: Getting worse. Now its 3hours ost. Any fix?

title: Can Huawei replace HTC in the US Market?

thread.text:
Folks,
Bloggers have been writing about and predicting the "death" "or exit from the phone market" of HTC for years now, and that talk has been surfacing again of late. LG and Moto are probably in a better position in the US market already than HTC. SO can Huawei, and their funky fresh junior brand Honor, make a real splash in the US Market if/when HTC leaves it? IF they leave it? Or maybe either way?
From a personal standpoint. I have owned and LOVED the Mate 9. I really loved the EMUI ROM. It was just enough customization with just enough closeness to the way "stock" versions do things. And the hardware itself was fantastic! I also had an Honor Z1 sports band/watch. While NOT a full fledged smart watch, it WAS pretty damn cool, and priced right!
So what do you all think? Is Huawei about to breakout in the US?
3rd place for global market share, not far from passing Apple and becoming 2nd to Samsung. It's only a matter of time until they do the same in America.
Yes they can absolutely do it. They just need to put in a solid effort, unlike what they have been doing so far.
It'll take time to break into America. Making solid phones are just not enough these days. They need to show off their phones and cash the ads out.

replies.text: They also need to do a better job updating phones... They officially have four phones in the USA and none are being updated as quickly as the Galaxy devices. One is still on marshmallow!
Yup. I love Huawei but they still need to improve themselves before thinking of dominating the US
They also need to be on all carriers...and they need to price aggressively at the beginning like OnePlus with an aggressive marketing.
Agreed. I would look at the Mate 10(I loved the Mate 9 overall) if they can improve a few things and definitely updates!
That's not sales driver though.

In the niche USA market that it is in now, updates will make a difference. 
Later, when it gains mainstream popularity then it would be less important, in terms of sales

thread.text: LG is the 3rd biggest manufacturer in the US right behind Apple. It's in a much better position than HTC. HTC with only 2-3% global market share, it'll be a piece of cake for Huawei to beat it in US.

Call quality is better.... As is the speakerphone for use in a meeting. My note didn't have much lag after 3 years surprisingly.... But this is another level of speed. The reviews are true! I think the mate is probably the fastest Android phone I've used.

I bought my wife a S8+ today. She wanted a larger phone and she was used to her Samsung S7. So I figured the couple of extra hundred dollars over the Mate9 would be worth it to keep her in her comfort zone (she doesn't like switching phone manufacturers). 
Working the S8+ confirmed everything that I thought. It is noticeably less fluid than the Mate9. It sure feels good in the hand though -- the Mate9 is a bit wide and she probably wouldn't have enjoyed it, especially since she likes thick cases (she's dropped her phone once or twice and the cases have saved them).
Also don't care for the 2:1 screen ratio. I prefer the 16:9 on my Mate.

thread.text:
Hey everyone!
My current daily driver is a KEYOne. I like that phone very much, especially the PKB. But I don't need the PKB all the time. When I am on trips, or just tooling around I started to notice that the small screen size was a bit annoying. Also, the older processor meant that it was a bit laggy at times and apps just take a bit longer to open than I would like.
So I started to look for another device that I could use in addition to the KeyOne. I discovered the Mate9 from a friend who had one. He raved about it, and so that stuck in my mind. 
I went to BestBuy this morning looking at the Galaxy S8+. I have bad memories of Samsung products though. Both my S6 and S7 started life off well enough, but within a few weeks of getting it -- the stutters and lag were just too much.
So I was looking for something much faster. And looking at the S8+ in the store brought back the stutter memories as I watched a slow frame rate S8+ display model do its thing. It was more fluid than my S7 but still not great compared to the Mate9 I had observed. Coupled with the $200 difference between the phones clinched it. I got the Mate9. I also didn't like the tall display. When looking at things in landscape, sites got funky. Sites without good mobile optimizations still work decent on a 16:9 screen so I often go into landscape for those kinds of sites. This seemed terrible on the S8+. It was also awkward for me to hold. I also do read eBooks, and so the tall screen ratio doesn't seem to work well for me.
But I have been pretty impressed with the Mate9 so far. I'm still trying out the camera, that seems to be where the phone might let me down. I hate the phony "wide aperture" mode. The zoom is nice, but the images seem a bit grainy. This is where the Samsung seems to have the Mate9 beat. Oh well, can't win them all (right now).
But the performance is excellent. Reminds me of an iPhone but with the power of Android. The dimensions are good -- and it even came with a little case and a screen protector which surprised me. All of the packaging materials were excellent. The charger took no time to charge it from 50% -> 100% even while doing updates in the background.
For $449 this thing is a bargain.
I don't think the Google keyboard is very good (okay, I hate it), but that could also be the PKB residue in me. Anyone got a good keyboard recommendation?
I'm also looking forward to the IR blaster! Good to have that on a phone again.
I'm just enjoying a nice (what appears to be) 60fps smooth experience with Android after my Samsungs. Hope it lasts!

replies.text: Give Swiftkey a try and play with the settings. It's the keyboard I use on all my phones.

thread.text: I have the keyone and the Mate 9- both good but Mate 9 is amazing. I'm using a S8+ right now so I can use wifi calling. Miss my Mate sometimes and get it out and look at it- seems so much BIGGER than the S8+. It's one of my favorites and I will def be looking to try the 10.

I have found that the Mate9 camera is rewarding if you are willing to work it. Particularly if you shoot in Pro mode or want to stay with the monochrome sensor to get rich Black and White photos. It is different from the typical prosumer snapshot camera. I am digging it more and more.

title: Absolutely no Huawei repair avaliable in the US

replies.text: Can't you send it in to them to repair it?

thread.text:
I broke my screen last week. Local repair shop charged me $80 to fix the screen with a black screen and $90 with a white, not OEM though. 
I contacted Huawei and they charged me $98 plus tax and shipping, came out to $113. I shipped my phone to them on Friday to their repair center in Texas.

replies.text: Thanks, that's good to know there is a stateside repair center. I did call Huawei and explained I wanted to have my Mate 9 screen replaced because I dropped it, I also asked about the price and was told $115, no problem, but the person I talked too said that I would have to wait for an email from them, give them payment information, then send pictures of the screen, and pictures of the back of the phone and pictures of the IMEI. Then after that they would tell me how to go about getting it repaired. Something about all the emailing pictures and giving them a credit card number before even being told how to go about getting it repaired seemed a little weird for an OEM. Maybe it was just a language barrier because the person I spoke to was extremely hard to understand and didn't seem to understand a few questions I asked. I'll try calling them again and start over.

Yeah, I went through all that process. I had to pay for the repair first, credit card or paypal, then emailed them a screenshot of the payment along with the pictures and EMEI. About an hour after sending the pictures, they expect you to call them and verify your address and other information over the phone and then they'll send you your 2 day shipping label.

thread.text:
I called Huawei/honor about a warranty repair for my honor 8 last year.
They sent a shipping label overnight.
Put the phone in the provided padded envelope applied the label and sent it to Texas on a Tuesday.
I had the phone back Friday morning repaired.

Huawei has small market share in the US, it's a foreign phone, will be harder to find parts and support for just like a foreign car. Smaller repair shops focus on Samsung and iPhone. I've seen issues getting parts for Motorola phones, and shops that refused to work on HTC phones locally. 
As others have already said, contact Haewei themselves, it seems like they can get it fixed for you.

title: Camera audio error message with 'OK Google' phrase detection

thread.text:
Hi
Does anyone have a work around to this irritating problem with Huawei Mate 9? I have raised this 4 times with Huawei Support and keep getting asked to expect a software update but it's been 4 months now and there is no sign yet of an update. I don't expect one anytime soon.
The problem is:
If you choose the option to have 'OK Google' detection from any screen switched on (which is one of the many great Android features of 6.0 and above), the camera keeps popping an error message saying 'Camera is currently recording audio. com.google.android.google/quicksearchbox:interactor will not be able to record right now'. So essentially the Camera's software is trying to say, you can't use the OK Google keyword while the camera is on. Yes, I understand that, and I won't use this feature. But why do you have to keep popping this message every 2 seconds, even when I'm using the camera!
The last time I called Huawei, I was told there was a work around till the time an update was released. I was happy to hear that but the next minute I was told, the work around is to switch the OK Google hotword detection off! Some workaround!
Any ideas anyone may have to work around this problem (i.e. continue using OK Google hotword from any screen but not have the Camera pop up that irritating warning) will be much appreciated.
Thanks!
Sachin
Hi what software are you on.?? this was fixed a while ago(usa)with an update .!

Thanks Freddyttt
I'm on Android 7.0 and EMUI 5.0. I'm in Australia and I wasn't aware that Huawei had released an update to fix this in the USA. Makes me angrier that the update hasn't been rolled out globally...

same problem i have got a solution.
turn of the google voice search service from the google settings it will not showing this again. thanks

Just got this phone. Don't know how I missed seeing it. Absolutely great. One question. On running some initial tests it seems that it is slower than my LG V20 with LTE speed even though they should have comparable capabilities. It may be just how T-MOBILE is working right now in my area. So, question, what kind of LTE performance are you seeing on T-MOBILE? In parts of my town I have seen 50-70 Mbps on my LG V20. As I have snail paced DSL in my home fast performance on my cellphone is very important to me. I have the MHA-L29 from Amazon. 
Thanks.

My T-Mobile LTE depends on where I am, it can be as slow as 5-12 M, or slower in center city Philadelphia which has BAD wireless saturation for ALL carriers (Verizon was just as bad for me at "work") BUT when I am at home or out and about in the neighborhoods of Philly I often see the 50-70 (or more) that you are talking about, and certainly at least 20-30.
I have an S8 and an Iphone 7 Plus.

replies.text: So, you are the person that can answer my question. I have recently tested an iPhone 7 Plus and it does get comparable data throughput to my V20-. The S8 has the most advanced modem Qualcomm offers. How does your Mate 9 compare to those devices? The same, slower or possibly faster? Spec-wise the Mate 9 COULD be the fastest modem although detailed specs are hard to find. I am just trying to determine how comparable the performance is with other top end products. Thanks.

Well I don't have the Mate 9 anymore so I'm going on memory, BUT I do remember it keeping pace with the my iPhone 7 Plus, BUT I own an S8 now and THAT has been beating the iPhone in speed tests. Last night my brother and I both ran speed tests at my parents house. On my s8 I was getting over 100M (100-120) down (30 to 40M up) at the same time on my iPhone I was getting 70-80 down and 20-30 up. My bother got similar to the iPhone speeds on his LG V10.
So for sure the S8 is a notch above, but I'm going to say as I recall the Mate 9 was in the same class as the iPhone.

Well the s8 supports more features like qam256 and 4x4 mimo. Depends on what the tower has too.
Peak speeds on my s8+ exceeded 200mbps. iPhone 7 plus was around 160ish. Apple intentionally dumbed down my iPhone 7 Plus with the Qualcomm baseband processor to match the inferior performance of the Intel baseband processor. So it doesn't surprise me that the mate 9 gets slower speeds than the s8+, because it isn't as feature rich, radio wise.

thread.text: Are these on the same LTE band? That could make a big difference.

Well the MHA-L29 does have all of T-Mobile's LTE bands. I had no issues with it when I had it. That's a Mate 9 for those not familiar with the item number name. lol It doesn't have the "new" 600mhz frequency though, which most of us don't have available to us either.

replies.text:
Sure but different phones can choose different bands, even if they all support the same bands. I have seen significant speed differences on the same carrier with phones capable of the same bands,which is why i asked.
Also Carrier aggregation can come into play.

Carrier aggregation is what I have been pondering and it is the one question I can't answer. The Mate 9 is supposed to support it in general but apps like LTE Discovery don't seem to work. Yes, they show an LTE connection but no band detail at all. Other apps act the same way. That is why I am asking for input as I can't tell by the normal means
Have you tried to contact the developer of the apps? They might be able to update the app to provide the data you need.

thread.text: No silicon currently supports 600Mhz although it is rumored that the Qualcomm modem currently paired with the Snapdragon 835 is being tweaked as we speak and NEW 835 projects such as the Note 8 MAY support that. But I live in the Chicago suburbs and we won't see 600Mhz for years. Sadly.

Additionally the S8 and other forthcoming phones will support T-Mobiles just releasing LTE-U technology (or whatever it's called) that they are rolling out on their newly acquired 600mhrz spectrum. Not yet in Philly.

replies.text:
Lte-U refers to unlicensed spectrum (like Wi-Fi) , i believe in the 5ghz range, which only the s8 is capable of utilizing on T-Mobile but currently has bee deployed in 6 smaller cities. I am not sure if unlocked phones in the future like a future mate will support it anytime soon
600mhz is licensed spectrum that T-Mobile won at the FCC as auction. This hasn't been deployed for public use yet but is upcoming. Not sure if the s8 will be able to use this.

title: Upon close inspection, screen scratches (at least for me and I am easy on phones)

thread.text:
This was the first phone I decided that I decided to ultimately go with no screen protector. 
I took off the factory one about a month in. I put on a new one. It was just okay but didn't seem to fit right. Took it off for about a week. Then, I was going to do some international travel so I bought a different brand protector and put it on. When I got back to U.S. last week, I took it off.
Now, because I am a phone geek, I bought a new phone and decided to sell this one. I had already typed up the Swappa ad but needed to take some pictures.
It's then when I noticed lots of little scratches on the screen and one slightly more signigicant one.
Yes, I know scratches can happen for all sorts of reasons. The more significant one was probably just an unlucky incident. However, I didn't expect all the little scratches especially from what I would consider maybe 4-6 weeks of exposure.
I don't drop phones. I keep cases on my phones. I don't do careless things in general with my phones. I am always aware of where I put it and how I set it down.
Back to using screen protectors, I guess. This is mostly an "FYI" but open to discussion too.

Unfortunately, even something like a speck of sand can scratch the screen, so it doesn't really Surprise me. A tempered glass screen protector is a good investment for sure if you want to keep your screen mint. Or in your case avoid further damage.

replies.text:
I usually use tempered glass protectors because they offer the next best thing to going bare. However, on this Mate 9, there really aren't any good ones available. The curving of the screen makes it tough. I bought a couple and ended up just not using them. The fit was... weird. I'm discovering similar fit issues when it comes to the Galaxy S8+. I went ahead with a film protector so I don't have this problem again.
My Mate sold in one day despite my disclosure of the scratches. Didn't make a lot on it but someone else can enjoy it now.

Yeah the curved edge screens make tempered glass screen protectors difficult. They tend to have a halo at the edges or tend to be too small. Guess the question is how picky you are about having a well fitting screen protector, and also how important resell is.

My biggest problem with those glass protectors is, like you said, they really have to be too small. Then, you find yourself swiping over the edge of them all the time which is a really bad experience.
Another thing I didn't mention was finding a good film protector for the Mate wasn't easy either. I ended up getting one through eBay that was the best. None of the major film companies want to make one for the Mate. They consider it a low volume phone (I asked).
Since I cycle through phones a lot, I need to keep that resell in mind.

Yeah i am the same as you. Resell is very important to me too. Unfortunately the mate 9 sells in very small numbers in the USA at least relative to other major USA flagships so that's probably why the major USA film makers didn't make something for it. Just the way it goes when you buy a lesser known phone, at least as far as the USA is concerned.
With regards to tempered glass, i prefer the halo to too small as the halo should still give you access to the screen.

title: Would a Samsung S8 be a good trade for a Mate 9 even trade?

I would say $550-580 if you have the Samsung factory sim unlocked model based in recent Swappa sales. The two low ones are excluded because one has no accessories and one has no box. 
You can take that money and buy a mate 9 on Swappa in Good condition for around$400
If it is not factory sim unlocked then pricing could be different as say you got a T-Mobile s8 and unlocked it either through T-Mobile or through flashing... you would not be able to activate it through Verizon's or Sprint's activation system as the IMEI isn't in the database. Of course this depends on the buyer but normally, such a disclosure would reduce price, if applicable in this case.
Also, if the s8 is on a device payment plan then that would need to be paid off before selling on Swappa.

thread.text:
Performance wise the Mate 9 is still faster than the S8. Interface on the Mate 9 is smooth like butter while kind of janky in the S8.
The camera is slightly better on the S8 when left on auto.
1440p vs 1080p
glass/curves vs aluminum
Honestly you can probably sell your S8 for 600 or so and pick up a new like new mate 9 for 500 or so.

Sell the S8 then get a mint mate 9 for 350 to 400 on Swappa and pocket the rest.
The mate 9 is a better phone if you like long batter life and big screen.
It's also got great cameras that are only outdone by the S8 in extreme low level like and even then only in auto. 
The Kirin 960 is actually faster than the 835 in various ways as well. 
One thing you'll notice is that Samsung phones tend to get janked up after a year or so and grind to a slow, batterylife crippling crawl. The mate 9 does no such thing. 
The mate 9s emui is an aquired taste tho. Many people can't get past it but if you don't spend a lot of time in the settings menu you should be fine just installing Nova launcher and calling it a day. 
I don't miss any other phone since getting my mate 9, and have had them all. I will say I keep a G6 in deck just for the wide angle lens, but that's the only reason why.

Why would someone want the Mate 9 over the S8?
The Huawei is a capable phone but is it better?

replies.text: I for one definitely want the Mate 9 over the S8 as I personally used an honor 8 for a long time and fell for EMUI stock. No launchers. I just happened to get such a good deal on the S8 that I could not pass it up. Plus my S8 is carrier branded free and fully unlocked was and on top of that it's in arctic silver which you can't get this color combo direct from Samsung like this. thread.text: If what you want is the other phone the why would it not be a fair trade to you?
I too wanted to try the P10 plus out but didn't see a version I'd be able to feel comfortable with buying.

I have M9 and S8+. The things that I personally found good/bad between the two: Wireless Charging on S8+, WiFi calling on S8+. I found the cameras to be almost equal. Battery (as everyone has said) amazing on M9. My huawei watch works perfectly on both.
BUT I'd sell the S8 and buy the Mate 9, You'll be able to sell it for more than you can buy Mate.

replies.text: This, I absolutely agree on all points.

thread.text: I prefer the Mate 9 over the S8 even though the S8 is a better phone. It's not a fair trade. I have both and I use the Mate 9, the S8 Plus is my GPS and my car media player.

Two weeks ago, I sold my Mate 9 and bought an S8+. So I did the opposite. 
First, no, it's not a fair trade. The S8 is currently worth more than the Mate 9.
The Mate 9 is a great phone. You can't beat the fingerprint sensor. So fast. The camera is excellent. I am not finding enough of a specs difference between the two phones to warrant picking one over the other. It's more in the subtleties. 
SCREEN: S8+ wins
Mate 9's 16:9 screen format is the typical format which is 100% compatible with apps, pictures, and movies. It's just HD IPS at 1080x1920 and that's really okay on a smartphones. As long as you aren't comparing, you really don't notice a whole lot.
HOWEVER - the Samsung has AMOLED and its deep blacks, high pixel density. Significantly higher resolution just make for a beautiful display. I was fine with the Mate but the S8 is striking.
CAMERA
From my amateur perspectove, I think they are an even match. The Mate 9 had a lot more camera features. The actual images look close to the the same. The Mate 9 camera is faster. 
SOFTWARE
EMUI? I used it for about 10 minures then switched to Action Launcher. I also ran into a few weird quirks on the Mate 9 with apps I used regularly (e.g. MightyText). I'm not seeing them on the wiidly popular S8.
My main reason for getting the S8+: I wanted to go back to using a mainstream phone and had my eye on the S8+. I change phones yearly. I had a 6P then the Mate 9.

title: A few reasons why I keep coming back to the Mate 9

thread.text:
I got the Mate 9 back in Feb and used it as a daily driver for a while and switched to a pixel XL, and LG G6. Ultimately I came back to the Mate 9 for a few specific reasons that are important to me.
1. Radio - it's incredibly strong. It's typically 4-10 db better than my G6 in the same location. I haven't found a phone that I have used that's better. I have been carrying both the G6 and Mate 9 lately and in areas the G6 has no signal the Mate 9 does. 
2. Battery life. It's just that good. 
3. Screen. It's incredibly bright. Do I care it's not a 2k display? Nope. I love this display even compared to the AMOLED Pixel. 
4. Camera. Specifically the black and white sensor. It's wonderful and can capture detail that is very pleasing to me. Overall the camera is not as good as the G6 or Pixel though just to be clear.

thread.text:
Yes. Next day shipping on Amazon Prime and this time it was free. It did arrive yesterday, but with one issue. I just missed the delivery and they sent it back to the distribution center until I answered where I wanted it left. The phone did arrive later that evening, but I had just enough time to set it up. 
First impressions though are this is an awesome phone! I immediately appreciated the fit and finish and the upscale feel of the phone. Very solid and well put together. Also, for a 5.9" inch screen I was shocked with how easy it was to handle. My Moto XPE has a smaller 5.7" inch screen but the Mate 9 was much easier to handle one handed and had a slightly smaller footprint in comparison. 
I downloaded the Google Launcher and set it as my default launcher and as of now, it feels like a typical Android phone. So far very impressed - great screen (watched Amazon Prime and it was very bright), super fast fingerprint scanner, nice speakers and super snappy/responsive doing routine searches. 
A couple of issues I need to work out though - it doesn't read my microsd card and says it needs to reformat it, which will delete everything on it. Definitely don't want to do that, so hopefully I can figure it out and secondly - its saying I don't have a mobile data plan, but its reading my sim (name and number). Looking into registering it on AT&T when I get home today. Hopefully that does it. 
Overall, great hardware and still need to figure out the software/camera. Very impressed though!

title: How to determine date of manufacture, no recovery mode on this phone, no barcodes

thread.text: Anyone know how to determine the date of manufacture for the Mate 9? It appears this phone doesn't have the normal recovery mode that I'm use to seeing on other phones, usually you can boot into recovery and see the manufacture date in the barcodes. This phone has no real recovery mode, I've tried every button combination I could think of, also not a single article on Google about it.

You're right...
All I get when I hold the the volume up and power keys together after shutting the phone off is a recovery screen with 3 choices.Reboot deviceRestore/recover deviceWipe cache
When I connect the phone to a PC and try a reboot from off using the volume down and power key HiSuite only offers the usual recovery option which wipes the phone to factory settings.
The phone does show a different "fastboot" screen using the connected option.

title: Does the Mate 9 being sold on Amazon work with Verizon?

Mate 9 has CDMA depending on region but not in the USA.

I thought CDMA was only used in North America...
GSM Arena has specs listed and it looks like it has every band, BUT 13.Huawei Mate 9 - Full phone specifications
A number of countries use CDMA outside North America. Many are phasing it out though. A list of countries:https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/List...A2000_networks

thread.text: Not according to Amazon:

replies.text: I don't understand this. I have a Google (Huawei) 6P and use Project Fi as a carrier (for now). Project Fi uses Sprint, T-Mobile and US Cellular towers. CDMA phones generally have to be white listed by the carrier.. Though Verizon will allow any phone with LTE band 13 due to FCC rules for that band.

replies.text: It should be able to pick up an LTE data signal in some areas with Verizon, but no band 13. And of course, you cannot make phone calls with it.

thread.text: So, the only thing keeping Sprint and Verizon from using this phone is permission? Really? You'd think that all carriers would want all possible phones on their rolls. That's just more money in their pockets. Either the carriers are stupid or there's something more to this.

replies.text:
Verizon only wants certified phones on its network. They want to insure that it will work to their standards. They are more than happy to certify any phone for usage on their network...for a hefty fee of course.
Without certification, Verizon doesn't want it on its network because it could be detrimental to Verizon's network, or it could give a poor user experience
