title: Huawei Mate 9 has serious problem to sync with MS Exchange

thread.text:
Hi dear,
I tested Mate 9 in last few days and everything is good and satisfactory. I use the smartphone to sync my work email from MS Exchange 2010. After installing the "Corporate" account to the phone, it sync with email, calendar and contacts fine with real time push. The next day after i power up the phone again. It could not sync the Exchange with error message "Sync is currently experiencing problems. It will be back shortly". Then all the sync with email, calendar and contacts are stuck.
I started to search the forum from Internet and followed the advice to delete the Exchange account, erase the data on "Exchange Service", Mail, Calendar and Contacts apps followed by a reboot. After that I reinstalled the Exchange account. All mail, calendar and contacts came back nicely. Real time sync was running good. Then I shut down the phone until the next day. This morning, it came out good and I thought i have resolved the issues. After testing a whole day and confirmed the real time sync working fine. I power down the phone again and wait for a few hours to see if there is any problem. When it powered up this evening, the same symptom happened again....sync error.
I used Samsung Note 2 and Note 4 before switching to Mate 9, so far Samsung worked nicely with Exchange without this kind of problem. I am a heavy user on Exchange email using the phone, now the phone is useless to me, very frustrated!!!
Will try to call the customer service center tomorrow but just wonder if they can help on this kind of software compatibility issue.
Any advice or assistance from this forum is much appreciated!
Thanks!
Wong

2010 era software working with Android newest OS seems like comparability could be one issue. 
What phone and OS did you have before? In all events, having a known trustworthy backup device is a must. 
In ancient past they use to have to certify disk drives and controller boards to work, plus with the host OS That may seem quaint but it still does happen. 
<http://forums.androidcentral.com/google-samsung-galaxy-nexus/271616-how-i-fixed-issue-my-samsung-phone-not-syncing-exchange-server-using-activesync.html>
<https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/10047/troubleshoot-activesync-with-exchange-server>

Add this reference - good walk thru of server side. Common to have issues with Android phones, especially when a new OS.
<http://www.techrepublic.com/blog/google-in-the-enterprise/troubleshooting-android-activesync-problems-with-exchange-2010/>
* <https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/mt465748(v=exchg.150).aspx>
* Seems to require desktop computer

Thanks for the kind assistance!
Is there any known compatibility issue between Exchange 2010 and Android 7 ?

I assume yes, for now. Technet would not load on my Mate 9.
Enable dev mode and logging events should help someone on admin side.

Alternatively, you might try a third party app to use your corporate email. I use an app called "Nine" - Not only does it work flawlessly, it has a lot of useful features. It's expensive by app standards but it is an outstanding mail app.
And, supported. $10 for that sounds like a bargain.

I use MS Exchange for work as well. I think they upgraded us to 2013 a few years ago. I don't have any issues with it. 
You can install Microsoft Outlook and log in with your work credentials and it should link up.

I connect to two Exchange accounts - one on 2010 and the other on 2013. Both work fine with no issues whatsoever. I also have one iMAP account and two POP3 accounts. None of them have issues either. 
I love this phone and have zero problems with it but there sure seem to be a lot of other people whose experience is different - apps that are compatible for some and incompatible for others, Exchange issues, etc.. Sometimes these issues fix themselves after a reset, other times not. I don't know if I'm lucky or it's just a matter of time before I experience some weirdness.

Today, I reinstall Exchange account to native email app and then install "Mail Wise" and "Outlook Android". I tried 3 apps at the same time. Working in the office in the whole day using public wifi. Everything fine for 3 apps. I powered down and powered up a few hours later, still it could connect to server and sync well. I tried several times and every time it was good. Then I went back home and use my wifi at home. The speed is about 200Mbps in term of actual throughput. Now problem happened again. The native email app and Mail Wise could not sync and Mail Wise indicated that it could not connect to the server. Interesting enough, Outlook Android was still working perfectly.
Now it shows that Android 7.0 has compatibility issue or setting issues with Exchange 2010 but Outlook Android can live with this without problem. Will try to see if the two dead apps can reconnect to the server when i go back to office tomorrow. If it fail again, i will remove the apps and try gmail app.

Now I come back to office and use the public wifi at home to test again. Both native email app and Mail Wise can connect to the server. Everything working fine again. That's mean I need to check my wifi setting at home. I guess some new security protocol may have introduced by Android 7.0 which is barred at my home wifi.
Problem resolved. I cleared the cache of the email apps of the phone which have problem. Now it is working fine at my home wifi. Nothing has been changed at my home wifi in term of setting.

After everything was working fine in last 2 days, tonight the same problem happened again using either home wifi or mobile data. I have cleaned up the app cache and reboot the phone. Still the national email app and Mailwise could not connect to Exchange server. I use the browser to login onto OWA, the email worked fine which means the phone could connect to the Exchange server through the browser but not the apps.
I would very much suspect the email apps have some issues with Android 7.0.

Previously only available on IOS, Material Design-themed Email by EasilyDo now available on Android, simply called "Email. " Supposedly the fastest email app in the market and the best one for Unsubscribing. I just installed it, I was able to add my work email, yahoo and Gmail without a problem.
Might solve your issues.

replies.text: I tried easily do Email yesterday and it is great. Fast and easy to use. Thanks for letting the forum know.

thread.text: Hi Dimas, thank you for the suggestion. EasilyDo is a good app for personal life organiser but may not be good to mix with business email.

Problem has been resolved. There is a new security setting at Android 7.0 when you set up Exchange server. "Security Type --> SSL/TLS (Accept all certificates)". I changed to this setting instead of "SSL/TLS". So far it is working fine.
Well, I'm having issues with work exchange email. I keep getting an error, "Failed to send email, connection problem" - I tried the "SSL/TLS (Accept all certificates)" but that didn't work.

Long post ahead. Tl;dr, I'll probably keep the Mate 9, but it will likely become a backup to the Pixel XL.
I got the Mate 9 three weeks ago and had been using it as my daily driver until yesterday when I received the Pixel XL I ordered back in February from the Google store (two weeks earlier than I thought).
Before the Mate 9 I was using the V20, which I've had since launch. I got the V20 to replace my Nexus 6, which now lives in my car, and was generally happy with it though I will say the speaker left a bit to be desired. I bought the V20 mainly for screen size and the fact it had Nougat out of the box. Second screen is cool, but I can live without it. Certainly not a gimmick though. Removable battery wasn't important to me nor were the quad DAC or the other advanced audio/video recording features. 
I bought the Mate 9 thinking I'd give it a shot since it also had a big screen, sort of stereo speakers, Nougat and great battery life due to the 1080p screen. I was generally happy with it, but the aggressive power management (which can be dealt with but takes a lot of tinkering), the weird notification quirks, and the overly complex settings were starting to bug me. Don't get me wrong, it's a great phone, but these little things can be annoying. It's also a big phone (as is the V20, which is nearly as wide and a tad taller albeit with a smaller screen not counting the second display).
Fast forward to yesterday when my Pixel XL arrived. I know it's still the honeymoon phase, but man this is a nice phone. Yeah, the screen is smaller but with DPI adjustment it'll fit as much as either of the other two while still being readable. Battery life has also been pretty good despite all the playing around with it. Plus, and perhaps most importantly, stock Android. It's nice to not have to use Nova, mess with settings to make it like stock, and otherwise just be able to enjoy the phone. It also feels good in the hand and is much more manageable than the V20 or Mate 9. Time will tell, but I'm really digging it.
Ultimately, I think the Pixel XL will become my daily driver, with the Mate 9 as a secondary/backup phone. I'll probably sell the V20, though that is also TBD. 
I'll end by saying all three phones are really good and, depending on one's individual needs, I would not hesitate to recommend any of them. 
If you made it this far, thanks for reading.

thread.text:
I won't. I adore my Mate 9. The battery life is insane, it's lightning quick, and it's super well built. I think the camera is definitely good enough, too.
One of my biggest complaints with the taller phones is that it takes my biggest problem with the current aspect ratio and makes it worse. When I'm viewing pictures and other media, I don't want the black bars. On the ultra-tall phones, they are actually dramatically reducing the dimension that's limiting how large you can display media. We kind of have to work the math backwards here since they measure the hypotenuse when they say 5.8 or 6.2, but the aspect ratio is 18.5:9 on Samsung's new phone. 
a^2+b^2=c^2 is our formula
18.5^2 is 342.25
9^2 is 81
Which means the hypotenuse, in the ratio is the square root of 423.25, or ~20.57
So now we work that back to get the width of the phone:
6.2"/20.57 is ~.3, so that's what we'll use to get the rest of the dimensions of the screen
18.5*.3 is 5.55"
9*.3 is 2.7"
So, let's see if it works: 2.7^2+5.55^2 is ~38.1, and the square root of ~38.1 is ~6.2 (It's 6.1725... but we got close enough)
That means the width of 2.7" is the restraining dimension on the phone.
Now lets go to 16:9 aspect ratio and see how big of a phone we'd need at that size to get the same width. More maths:
2.7/9 is (you guessed it) .3
16*.3 is 4.8 (.7" shorter than your tall screened phone)
Now we figure out the triangle 2.7^2+4.8^2 = 30.33
And the square root of 30.33?
5.5"
Do the same for the smaller Samsung and you get 5.15"
If those numbers look familiar at all, it's because they are. Those are the sizes of the Galaxy S7 edge and the S7. Photos and videos won't be able to be displayed fully any larger on Samsung's new S8, even though it has a bigger screen. I thought both those phones were too small for my personal preference, which is why I went with the Mate 9.
And on my Mate 9, when I shoot 3:4 photos for full resolution, or take photos from my camera, I still get the black bars, so I don't want to exaggerate that.
Now all that being said, it would have been real nice to get an OLED display, and maybe the higher pixel density, and perhaps a better set of lenses on the back, but this phone runs so damn fast and efficient that I really have a hard time complaining about anything.
Samsung and LG can keep their faux-large screen phones. I'll keep the Mate 9.

thread.text: That's normal. Unless you install a 3rd party app like Stay Alive!, you can't make the screen stay on indefinitely (at least not while it's unplugged).
I want to change voice to txt default from Google to Hound. How do I do this?

No idea what Hound is, but if it register as a valid Voice-To-Text service on your phone, you should be able to set it as the default on the 'Language and Input' section of your Settings as a Keyboard. If it doesn't appear there, then the app isn't registering as a voice-to-text alternative and unless there's an in-app setting that allows you to override the phone's stock voice-to-text service, it won't be possible to set it as default. It will also depend on the Keyboard you're using (some force their own voice recognition software).
Hound is voice to txt search engine similar to sirix

title: What is the encryption situation with the Mate 9?

thread.text:
I have gathered that the Mate 9 is not completely encrypted. I see no settings for encryption. I've done a little research and I've read something about the data partition being encrytped but I'm not sure I understood that information. It mentioned something about running into problems when rooting... not sure.
I asked on Amazon and got a response from Huawei USA that was not reassuring. It said they have a "vault" you can protect with your fingerprint and that it's a "safe phone."
Does anyone know if this phone is encrypted at all? If so, which part?
I say give XDA a try.
What did you find out about this?

I have learned that the Mate 9 is definitely not entirely encrypted. There's a good chance none of it is encrypted. It does let you create an encrypted space on the phone. It appears you may be able to encrypt your microSD card though.
I am in the assessment phase of this phone. It works amazingly well. It's a really great phone. I have this small concern that it's a Chinese phone and it might not be repspecting the privacy of my data. What if it's like the Blu phones that sent data to China on a regular basis? I installed two apps that track communication between the phone and servers to see what comes up. So far, it's just found a couple apps communicating within the U.S. and nothing unexpected.
I also need to think about how important it is to me to have an entriely encrypted phone. I went without for years until I got my 6P. I know there is this big debate over encryption. I'm planning on sticking with this phone for about a year. I'm still thinking.

replies.text: What's China going to do with your data? All phones/computers in the US are being spied on by the government anyway.

thread.text: If you're online there is no privacy, chances are you are being spied on even if you're offline. The government even listens to landline calls.
US government has told their employees to stay away from Huawei.

replies.text: Bump. Still looking for some opinions.

thread.text:
I've been looking into this too because I really want the Mate 9 but I'm not willing to give up Verizon. 
From what I've been able to tell if you get the international model (MHA-L29, which you can get on Amazon or B&H) you have a chance. It's missing LTE band 13, which is 700 MHz and much better for getting into buildings and in rural areas, but it still has 2 and 4 at 1900 and 1700 MHz. It has CDMA support, but I can't tell if it's the right "flavor" of CDMA. 
Ultimately, Verizon is going to have to "approve" it to be on the network, and in order to determine that, you need to plug in the IMEI or some other ID number into their tool here: http://forums.androidcentral.com/e?l...token=B7S1cHFq
Does anybody have an MHA-L29 and want to PM me the IMEI, ESN, or MEID number?
For me, the killer might be no 700 MHz support on Verizon. It has the 700 MHz LTE bands for T-mo and AT&T. As much as I love the design, even if I could get it to work on Verizon, I'm not sure I want to neuter my connectivity just to have this phone.

Welp, I stopped by the local Best Buy to fondle the S8+ and the Mate 9. They happened to have the MHA-L29 model as the display, so I looked up the IMEI (it had two) and dropped them both into Verizon's compatibility checker. No dice, it said it's not compatible. I guess I shouldn't be surprised.
Maybe there is a way to get them to activate it anyway, despite what that tool says. I thought about buying the phone, testing it out and then returning it if it doesn't work. But after careful comparison I think I'm going to go with the S8+ instead, for better or worse.
Thank you for the replies Rumline, TylerLV76.

For what it's worth, when I had my Mate 9 and was still on Verizon I tried to get the phone to work. Somewhere on this forum I posted my experience and got the reasoning behind why it won't work in the US. The type of CDMA wasn't compatible in the US. I had a sim that was activated and working in an iPhone so it was already provisioned. The phone would detect the sim but wouldn't connect what so ever to Verizon. It could tell it was a Verizon sim but that's it. It would show full bars then after a second it would x out and show "no service".
That's probably a Verizon thing. They are very controlling and don't like devices on their Network they didn't approve.

The Mate 9 probably will be my next phone, as I really like to have a big screen for media consumption. Just want to see if any of Mate 9 owners have a battery case, and if you do, how do you find it.
Otherwise, if you did use a battery case for another phone, would love to hear your opinion also.
This is what I see on eBay:For Huawei Mate 9 10000mah External Battery Backup Charger Case Power Bank MP | eBay
Thank you!

FWIW, the battery life on the Mate 9 is pretty darn incredible. If you pick the phone up, you might actually find you don't need a battery case. Really, it's that good.
The case you have a link too is pretty inexpensive. Not sure how they can pack a 10,000mah battery in it though. Too good to be true? Maybe but for $18 (US) doesn't appear to be too risky to give it a try.
All that said, unfortunately the aftermarket manufacturer's don't appear to be giving much love to the Mate 9 so there's not a lot out there. My guess is this is because even though it's a great phone, it's probably not selling in high enough numbers to warrant the cost to build accessories for it. That's a shame, it really is a great phone.

I find that not all cables work, same for chargers. It's requirements may be unique. And then there's the super quick charge, very fast. 
Huawei MateBook compatible? And I would not take chances like person tried hooking up phone to an auto battery! 🔥🔥
Just bought spare Huawei charger Amazon, $42. 
I have a couple battery packs I'll try out Wednesday.

title: Finally got for my phone for the next 6+months.

thread.text:
After a month of trial and error, I settled on the Mate 9. It'll be my phone at least until the S8 comes out.
My S7E was the first phone I had for over 12 months and it served me well, but was also pretty beaten up, so I took advantage of a T-Mobile Jump eligibility to get my wife a new iPhone. 
For myself I tried: Honor 8. Great little phone, but the Mate 9 was more my fit. Google Pixel. (XL wasn't available, so I guess that would make the Pixel a "Rip off price" phone according to that other thread). Kidding aside, it is a good phone, but the camera for my use was not comparable to the S7E, and no other function justified the price. Maybe if I had tried the XL, I would have seen it differently, but the camera and overall feel of the phone was just not that appealing to me .
Anywho, very exited about the Mate 9, but manageable, screen is fine, camera is good (not S7E good though), everything is flying, and if it wasn't for lack of waterproof, I would probably keep it longer than when the S8 comes out.

replies.text: Interesting comments on the camera. I really like the Mate 9 but am considering going back to my Pixel XL BECAUSE of the camera (I have both). It just seems like every picture taken with it comes our wonderfully clear. I had the S7 Edge too (sold it after getting the Mate 9) and still think the Pixel offers the best camera. Not arguing - just interesting how people have different perspectives.

Yeah, I read so much great about the Pixel camera and I did manage to take great pictures occasionally, it just wasn't as consistent and effortless as the S7E. So for the price the M9 just looked good. And so far very happy with it.

I am reading all the comments about how good the Mate 9 camera is, but I just don't see it. I've had my phone for a week and may return it due to the camera. 
In 20 mp mode, it's unusable almost. Every picture I take if blurry when you zoom in. Horrible detail composites to my note edge. Maybe there is something wrong with my phone physically?

title: Video playback issue with videos I've taken on phone

thread.text:
Hi Everyone:
I got the Mate 9 last week. This weekend I captured great quality regular 1080P video (see setting screenshot) of my daughter figure skating. I'm thrilled with how it came out. But for some reason when I play it back regardless of whether that's in the Gallery app or in Google Photos, it freezes around 17s in and only audio continues. 
If I force it past 17s, I can watch a bit more before it happens again. Same thing with other videos.
Any suggestions?
Thanks
Tamir

Both Google Photos and the Gallery app are primarily focused on photos, with video playback being a more incidental feature. Try installing either 'MX Player' or 'VLC' and see if you're able to view your videos properly. Both are very capable multimedia viewers. (I've been using both and currently prefer MX Player because its Settings menu has a lot more customizing and optimizing options. But either one can handle a wide range of file formats and both have nice user interfaces.)https://play.google.com/store/apps/d...layer.ad&hl=enhttps://play.google.com/store/apps/d...olan.vlc&hl=en

Oh and just a reminder, be sure to back up those videos. In Google Photos, confirm in Settings >> Backup & sync that the 'Videos' option is enabled so they also get backed up into your online Google account. If you don't have a decent online connection that will most likely take a while as high res video can be quite sizable so if bandwidth is an issue than at least be sure to manually back them up -- preferably to a computer but at least to a microSD card if you've added one to your Mate 9.

replies.text: Thanks a lot. I checked on a regular computer and it played fine from Google Photos, so I've now downloaded VLC player and it is working. I have to admit this is the first phone where I've had to download this. But at least I have a way to do it. Thanks again.

replies.text: It has quick charge 3. Fast charging is there in it.

Hi,
Yes it is, but not for Huawei gear. Sorry but your information is misleading.Qualcomm fast chargers are none compatible with Huawei products which use HiSilicon fast charger technology. 
Anyone who follows your advice will have a charger that will work, but will neither fast charge nor supercharge any Huawei product.

Not sure where you got that info from but it's wrong. The mate 9 will take advantage of quick charge 2.0 and 3.0 however it isn't as fast as the proprietary Huawei supercharge. It all depends on the cable. If you use Huawei's cable with QC 3.0 chargers you will achieve speeds in the 2000+mA range. Without the Huawei cable you will be under 2000mA. With the Huawei block and cable you will be 3500+mA. 
It will only say supercharge on the screen with Huawei's charger and cable. It will never say fast charging.

thread.text: Hi. I have a selection of Huawei Superchargers and Huawei Quick chargers. I also have Qualcomm 3 chargers. With the Supercharger and original cable the Mate 9 will show "Supercharge". With the Quick charger be it with its original cable or the one from the Supercharger. "Fast charge" is displayed. With a Qualcomm 3 charger, yes the mobile will charge. The display on the Mate 9 shows "charging" but no matter what cable you use, the speed of charging will never match either the Huawei Quick charge or Supercharger plugs.

Have you measured the charge in ampere? I use an anker quick charge 3.0 charger with the Huawei cable an get upwards of 2400mA. With another cable I get around 1500mA using the same quick charge 3.0 block. With the Huawei charger and cable I get 3500mA up. Never has the phone said "fast charging" with any combination of blocks and cables. There's been multiple discussions on this very topic on XDA with the same results.
So no the speeds won't match but to say they aren't compatible and will not fast charge is not correct.

Hi, I will measure the different chargers and cables this evening (UK time.) I can assure you though that if you use a Huawei Quick charger (as distinct from the Huawei Supercharger) on the M9, it will show up as "Fast Charge" with any Huawei cable.

replies.text:
Keep in mind, you are most likely on a different variant of the device. I have a Huawei Quick Charger coming tomorrow and will test it. So far the results I have are:
Huawei SuperCharger and Huawei cable - 3500+mA (SuperCharging)
Huawei SuperCharger and other cable - 1500mA (Charging)
Anker QuickCharge 3.0 with Huawei cable - 2000+mA as high as 2400mA (Charging)
Anker QuickCharge 3.0 with other cable - 1500mA (Charging)
ZTE QuickCharge 3.0 with Huawei Cable - 2000+mA (Charging)
ZTE QuickCharge 3.0 with other Cable - 1500mA (Charging)
Again, changing the cable makes the biggest difference because the Huawei cable uses 2 extra pins than a standard USB-C cable.

thread.text:
Hi, 
I have tested the chargers below. Didn't bother about using non-original cables except for one test, as I am well aware of the two extra pin issue for Samsung Supercharger cables. They are relatively easy to obtain in the UK whilst the Supercharger plugs are as rare as hen teeth. As expected. I got "Super Charge" displayed with the Huawei Supercharger plug. "Fast Charge" for the Huawei Quick Charge plug and "Charge" displayed for the Qualcomm chargers. 
Aukey Qualcomm 3 car charger with original Huawei cable - 1680mA.
Samsung fast adaptive charger with Huawei original cable - 1760mA. (1720mA with an expensive substitute cable).
Huawei Quick Charger with original Huawei cable - 2780mA
Huawei Supercharger with original cable - usually around 3200mA.
As far as I am concerned, yes you can use Qualcomm chargers for the Mate 9. However, you are much better off using Huawei chargers. Whilst here in the UK, the Huawei Supercharger isn't available, the Huawei Quick chargers are available, cheap and offer a performance advantage over any Qualcomm chargers. 
Cheers
Marsh

thread.text: Thanks Paul. I do wonder to what extent the existing charge level of the phone, has on the speed of charging. By that I mean, the mA will be higher if the mobile only has a 20% charge than if it is already charged to 90%. Frankly I don't have the time or patience to investigate. Perhaps someone here might.

replies.text: From what Ive seen it definitely changes the mA depending on the level of battery. For instance, the other night I put my phone on at 90% to measure some cables and every setup I used was at 1040mA including the stock Huawei cable and block. If you charge at say 30% battery you will get the highest numbers possible.
AH YES! OF COURSE! I need to check it again when I am at a lower charge level. Excellent point!

thread.text:
After doing a factory reset this morning and getting the battery to 45% I decided to measure all my cables and blocks. Some of my results were vastly different than before the reset.
The numbers are where the meter was after 60 seconds of charging. 
Anker 3.0 (Max 2.4a output) Generic Cable - 2260mA
Anker 3.0 (Max 2.4a output) Huawei Cable - 2310mA
Huawei Fast Charger Generic Cable - 3300mA
Huawei Fast Charger Huawei Cable - 3300mA
Huawei Super Charger Generic Cable - 2810mA
Huawei Super Charger Huawei Cable - 4510mA
The only block that made a significant difference with the Huawei cable vs generic cable was the SuperCharger block that comes with the phone. Based on those numbers Id say a QC 3.0 device will absolutely charge the phone at the rated speeds. On the anker charger it is near the top of the max output the charger can do. 
Now the odd part. Yesterday I got my Huawei fast charger in and plugged it into the phone to see if it said fast charging and it didnt. I tried again last night before going to sleep and still it just said charging. This morning I reset my phone and during the meter tests the phone said fast charging. I turned off ampere and plugged the Huawei fast charger in again and it again says fast charging. Not sure why a reset caused it to finally show but it is there both with the huawei cable and the generic cable.
In the end, I'd get yourself a quickcharge 3.0 charger and any usb-c cable. If the charger is rated at 2+ amps output, you're going to get 2+ amps. While it may not say fast charging, it certainly is charging rather fast.

Thanks Tyler. Your efforts are appreciated!
On this side of the pond, personally I would advise buying the Huawei fast charger, which comes as a package with the original Huawei cable. To buy a good quality quick charge 3.0 plug and a decent compatible cable, is around the same price and has "less bang for the buck" so to speak. 
Cheers 
Marsh

title: I got such a cool "case" but if you use it, you might as well give up the camera - Ugh.

thread.text:
I saw this cool case on eBay, essentially what I would call a bumper case, but it was all metal and customized to the point of requiring a screwdriver to install. So cool.
I bought it for around $7 and in typical ship-from-China fashion, it took weeks to get here. Finally got it.
I used it for about an hour. So cool. Sadly, had to remove it. It provides ZERO protection for the camera and most of the back. It's not thick enough to hold the phone above a surface. The phone just rests on its back, on the camera. I thought it would be thick enough to keep the back off of surfaces. Nope.
Anyway, thought I'd share it just because....
Got a similar one on my s7 edge. I got a skin for the back and camera. Theres some metal camera shields on ebay for my phone. Maybe theres some for yours too. Definitely worth checking out.

replies.text: Do you mean a skin that goes over the camera? A film you put over the camera? I assume that would affect the camera's shots.

Skinomi offers skins for the Mate 9 similar to dbrand and there is a portion that covers the camera glass while leaving holes for you to use the camera. It would prevent scratches but if you dropped on the back it would still crack. 
Skinomi TechSkin - Huawei Mate 9 Screen Protector + Dark Wood Full Body Skin / Front & Back Wrap Clear Film / Ultra HD and Anti-Bubble Shield https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01M27REN1...cUvbUpU5728381
Ah, get it. I still think this case is a bad idea because the actual camera lens isn't protected. Too easy to scratch it. It's cool though!

thread.text: The skin covers the camera glass but its got a hole in the middle to not intefere with yiur pics and videos.
Same boat. I found a cool case on Aliexpress fairly cheap, but I won't be using it and for the price, it's not worth returning it.

I don't know why they make them. I actually don't know what they were thinking when they designed the phone in such a way that it curves and rests on the camera lens. It does make it easier to hold though. I don't think it's worth the trade off to possibly damage the AMAZING camera.

I own a Honor 8, absolutely love it, Emui has become my favorite version of Android. I've always been a fan of bigger phones, so of course I want the Mate 9. After thinking about it for a long while, I've come to the conclusion that the Mate 9 is just a bigger Honor 8, I can't see spending the money to just get a bigger phone of what I already have. So, I've decided that the Mate 9 pro is the way to go, I get a true upgrade in everything that way, screen size, 2k vs 1080p, CPU with the 960 vs the 950, RAM, 6 gigs vs 4. Much better deal if you already own a Honor 8 and if you don't, get one, it's the best of the Mate 8 and the P9 put together in a sexy little package.

replies.text: The mate 9 us warranty has the 960 in it.

replies.text:
I'll do this one. First try Huawei's system. Go into the WiFi settings (where you see all the available SSID's) and turn on WiFi+ then give it a couple days. See if that works.
If not, try the app WiFimatic.
Unfortunately, I actually lean toward thinking that neither of these will work because moving around your house does not register but worth a try. Oh - unless you have a very big property. 
The other thing to consider is whether or not your signal is dropping so low that it is impeding your experiance on the phone.

thread.text:
Hell-o all!
Recently purchased the Mate 9 after having the honor 8 for a few months.
I'm a Nova user and was wondering if the small up arrow above the dock that brings up the app drawer pictured below can be disabled?I haven't encountered this feature previously with a similar setup on my Honor 8.
I'm not sure if this is something available in Nova or the phone firmware so I was hoping another Mate 9 owner could offer advice.
Any help would be very much appreciated.
Yep. Open Nova Settings, then App & Widget Drawers, and turn off the Swipe Indicator.

thread.text: I bought a Huawei Mate 9 pro from singapore. The home screen was showing and it has dissappeared

I'm interested in a Huawei Mate 9, but I'm discouraged by the lsrge weight of the device. I assume much of its weight comes from the massive 4000mAh battery. 
My lifestyle is such that I'm never more than 2 hours away from a charger. So I would give up battery life against less weight. 
Is any vendor producing lighter batteries? I checked the usual suspects (Ebay, AliExpress) but they still falling over competing on capacity.

How would you propose replacing the non removable battery with another one? I'm sorry but my guess is you're in the minority - most people want all the battery life you can get. My recommendation would be to get a smaller and lighter phone. Probably a heck of a lot easier.
It's also the aluminum. If you use this phone for a day you will notice the weight any more. What are you used to using?

I have a Mate 9 and a LG V20. Granted the screen size on the V20 is a little smaller, but it's a much lighter phone (smaller battery also, but removable). Ever since I got the V20 (around a month ago), it's been my daily driver. The Mate 9 is heavy, no question about it and even after months of using it, to me, it's still a heavy phone. 
The M9 is a great phone, I'm not really dissing it, just addressing the OP comments regarding weight and a possible atternative. For the record I also have a P9, so I'm not anti Huawei

Try just using "Recent" and close the app or click on the trash icon to close all apps.
What app, always same?
Clear app cache after Force Stop.
Clean setup? That always help.
Next, try clearing system cache.
What were you using before? Did it have 7.0?

I often have group texts with 5 people and it just can't keep up. There is scroll lag. If it's one o e conversation it's great. However because of those issues I'm between Google messenger and Textra.

thread.text: I downloaded Android Messenger, just to give it a shot, as I'm happy with Huawei's messenger. I made Android M the default yet uninstalled it because it would not recognize any of my contacts, it would say Unknown Sender.
The only way that I know that works for me is to delete the conversation and start a new conversation in Google messages and I think I rebooted the Mate 9 as well.
But then, it will replicate itself all over again. It is odd.

I was having a similar problem with my daughter (using a Samsung Active). Her messages frequently arrived as Unknown Sender, and in group MMS texts her messages would never download. Frequently her simple SMS texts to me would show as "Download Failed". So I switched to Textra and that resolved the issue, but I wasn't happy that I could not use the stock Message program or Android Messages. I called AT&T and they re-provisioned my Mate 9 on the account, and I reset the APN to Default in Settings and now everything works fine. Odd to say the least, but at least it works now.
Yancy

thread.text:
What's really odd is everything works perfectly in the Android auto app but when plugging into the stereo it gets crazy. You would think it would work the same as the car if it was an issue with the phone. 
What other phones have you tested?
Edit: I decided to go out to my car and test a few things. First I replaced the USB c cable I got from Best buy with the Huawei cable. I did have to re-engage the call screen like mentioned above the first time. Then I tested when I plug the phone in and unplug it. Unplugging it never made a difference whether the car was on or off. Plugging it in however did. If I waited to sync fully loaded before I plugged in, text messages wouldn't read. The dots came up but never played. However, if I plugged it in while the mustang splash logo (F-150 in your case) was up it worked perfectly. The call screen worked Everytime after switching cables and engaging it the first time. Text read perfectly as long as I didn't wait to plug the phone in. I don't know if it's truly the phone or is it sync itself, which as we know is not the most stable system. I can't tell you how many times my screens gone black and I had to turn the car off for 15 minutes for it to come back. Now you add Android Auto which has been quite buggy and who knows what's going on. 
Anyway, if you're using a 3rd party cable try and swap it out with the Huawei one and see if that helps. Maybe also try plugging in before the splash screen goes away.

title: Mobile data stopped working a couple minutes after startup/reboot

thread.text:
Hi,
I wonder if anybody has experienced the same weird issue that happened to my mate 9. The issue is that the phone would lose mobile data after maybe one month of use from fresh factory reset and once it started happening, it can't be completely fixed without a factory reset. The mobile data would come back for about 1 minute or 2 after reboot/ shutdown-startup and it will stop working. It is not a problem that it can't pick up again because I was in a bad reception area. It has good reception and the phone is stationary. When it stops working, the IP address field in About phone->status becomes unavailable. I have a feeling that the mobile data sub-system has crashed or something.. Do you know if there is a way to restart the mobile data sub-system /modem without rebooting the phone? I also have the LTE discovery app which shows I had LTE signal but it just won't connect. I tried toggling the mobile data switch, data roaming switch,..etc and it just wouldn't work again until a reboot/shutdown - startup. Please advise.
Carrier: T-Mobile USA (Sim 1 only, Sim 2 slot is empty)
Model number: MHA-L29
Build Number: MHA-L29C636B158
Baseband version 21.508.00.00.031

Try this.
settings> in the search type Mobile Network> press it then press it again till you see this. make sure Mobile data is always on.

Is this what you are looking for:
Settings, Notification & status bar, Notification management, settings cog (top right), When device is locked
There you can set notification content.

Hi I just got my Mate 9 and it's an awesome phone. The only thing I cant seem to do is change SMS sounds for each contact. Is there a way to do this? If not can someone recommend a good SMS messenger replacement? Thanks

Go into the contact, select the contact you want to change, click "add another field" click "phone ringtone" and select the on you want. 
If its contacts imported through exchange services you cannot do this as exchange controls the contact data.
Hi, I can setup a ringtone when someone calls but how do you set up a text tone for each contact. I like to have different text tones so I know who is texting me. Thanks

replies.text:
Follow the instructions I posted above. 
Open the contact you want to change the tone for, hit edit at the bottom, click "add another field" click "phone ringtone" and select the tone you want.

title: All these quirks, little incompatibilities and strange little behaviors

thread.text:
I have found all sorts of quirks and issues with apps and this phone. I honestly don't understand what causes these. LastPass' usage access keeps turning off. Macrodroid just stopped being able to read incoming texts. I can't use MightyText anymore. None of this happened on my previous phones nor is it happening on my currently active tablets. 
I have seen developers fix things "for Huawei phones." I've also seen statements like that for Samsung phones.
I am finding it all very annoying. These little things are the only notable downside for this phone. Can anyone shed any light on why this happens? The big picture?

For LastPass I had to set to exempt from optimization to get it to work properly:
Settings, Apps, Gear Icon (bottom of the screen), Special Access, Exempt from Battery Optimization
Select "All Apps", find Lastpass and set to "Allow".
Can't help with the other stuff, though I agree the phone has some quirky behaviors.

replies.text:
I believed it has to do with your Settings - > Display - > View Mode. It has Small, Medium and Large. Some app will shows incompatible depending on what's your setup. That setting is essentially the DPI setting. I had the same issue with Amazon app being incompatible after changing the View Mode. What I did to fix the problem was to change it back to the default Large, install Amazon app and change my View Mode to Medium and the Amazon app still works. Just no updates I guess because once I changed it to Medium, Play Store is saying the app is incompatible...
Hope this helps

thread.text:
It's weird because I run iHeart and if I let the phone lock itself after a minute or so, the app will run for a good while. Then after a while, the app will stop playing until I unlock the phone, then it tries to connect again.
Before this week, it wasnt happening, so who knows what's going on. I may have to tinker around with it.

replies.text: Possibly a power saving restriction. May need to exempt the app from any power saving. I know I was getting alerts that iheart radio was using high battery but I exempted it and havent had an issue since.

thread.text: So I had the same issue today with iHeartRadio as you guys. I normally run it in the car or while plugged in but today I ran it unplugged connected to a Bluetooth speaker. After 10 minutes it stopped playing till I woke the screen then it automatically resumed. So I'm fairly confident it's a power saving issue but for the life of me can't find a way to shut it off. I tested it with and without Bluetooth to make sure it wasn't Bluetooth shutting down and had the same thing. Not sure how to stop the software from pausing the stream without leaving the screen on.

Alright Ive found where to fix the issue. Go to: settings>apps>settings gear (bottom of screen)>special access>exempt from battery optimization>click drop down arrow next to "allowed">all apps> iheartradio>click "allow".
That should solve the issue. Ive been streaming unplugged for almost 2 hours with zero pauses. It seems the systems built in battery optimization recognized iheartradio as an app that can use alot of battery and pauses it after 10 minutes unless its exempt.
Hope this helps.

Cool. Thanks. 
iHeart now plays without stopping for me as well (also, the iHeart app got an update this week). Still using the Mate 9 as a DD. New out of the box, the aggressive battery optimizations took a while to "dig into" and figure out exactly what was what.
Since marshmallow Android has been a bit more proactive at reducing power consumption. And Huawei amps it up another notch with their software.
Normally when I travel I use my iPhone for the battery life and for the better app quality. I traveled last weekend and continued to use the Mate 9 as my DD. It's a keeper. And now this morning with the latest android February security update it gets even better.
PS: I have a Pixel XL and an iPhone 7 Plus so I have real experience with all these devices as a DD. So yeah I like the Mate 9.

title: Auto-brightness too sensitive in low light

thread.text:
Hello!
I must always disable auto-brightness when I'm in a low light environment (e.g. evenings, mornings when it's dark) because the Mate 9's auto-brightness is too sensitive. That is, it does a kind of loop, adjusting brightness to the minimum, then increasing a little, then decreasing to the minimum, then increasing a little......
I suspect the algorithm to be too sensitive, so that when displaying a page the light from the screen is perceived by the sensor which makes the auto-brightness to decrease, and so on...

When I long-press the home button to bring up the Google window, it prompts me at the top of the screen to say 'OK Google' but I can say it til I'm blue in the face, it doesn't notice. I have to press the little microphone icon. 
It's not something I really use, but perhaps I would if my phone would enter the ok Google mode just at my voice request to ask it something. Are there some settings I need to enable? 
Is it possible for Google to wake my phone from sleep using the ok Google command?

You should be able to access some options to enable "Ok, Google" by using the settings (hamburger) button on the top left from the Google app (the screen you reach by long-pressing the home button).
For what you are looking for:
Settings>Voice>"Ok Google" detection - First, enable "From any screen" and "Trusted Voice". This may or may not prompt you to train/retrain voice model. Go through the voice model training steps. The voice recognition will improve with use, as Google will learn any specific speech patterns or pronunciation that are personal to you.
As far as waking from sleep, that can only be done if the device is charging (some phones, such as the Moto X, had/have an always on listening capability.) But it's pretty nice to be laying in bed while your phone is charging and just yell at it to play some music or get some info.
have you enabled "OK emy " .....???

title: I have the Mate 9 and S7 edge...which one should I keep?

thread.text:
I purchased both of them on the same day, both unlocked and working on T-Mobile, and I'm not sure which one to keep. I love the Mate 9's 4000 mAh battery, Android 7.0, and the 5.9 inch screen and it's definitely the best big phone I've used since the Note7, but I love the SAMOLED display on the S7 edge as well as the IP68 rating. I think the low light photos are a little better on the S7 edge as well, but that's not a big deal.
Yes, I know this is a first world problem and it's a problem most people don't get to have, but I can only keep one of the phones anyways. Which one would you keep?

replies.text: I think you should keep them both and switch back and forth. I have the OPO3t and S7 edge and Mate 9 and 7+. I just pop the sim out of one and put it into whatever one I feel like using.....
I can afford only one to keep. I'm currently in a 14 day return period for both phones from Best Buy.
Amen. I thought I was the only one that did this 😀😀😀
I'm doing this now but with an iPhone in the mix. How do you keep all your text between devices?
I don't transfer text history between them. Everyone I text is in my contacts list. So that is synced through Google contacts. For me text history is not relevant. But I think some use SMS Backup.

I'm in the exact same situation, lol. The deal breaker with the mate 9 for me is the "themes". I think every phone should give the option for a "light" or "dark" theme. I prefer "black" backgrounds over "white". And when I say "black", I mean settings, contacts, dialer, messages etc.... Not just 1or 2 of these. And another issue I am having is within the messaging app. When I send a group message with a photo attached, the quality of the photo is really bad. I might have to give the 3t a try.

Personally for me, i would go with the Galaxy S7. Simply because it's got a nice IP68 Rating, its got a good low light camera AND the screen size is much more manageable. My hands are fairly small and a 5.9" inch screen is too big. I prefer the Mate 9's design and really big battery, but overall i think the S7 would be the better choice.

It depends on what you're looking for. I had both as well until recently.
Mate 9:
Better battery life, better performance, newer chipset, bigger screen, USB Type C, better speakers, Leica cameras setup is pretty fun to play with too.
S7 Edge:
More compact, Higher resolution AMOLED panel, nicer looking software design, IP68, superb camera performance, VR ecosystem, Samsung Pay.
Personally I really like the Mate 9, but the software design could use a bit of work. Even if you can use a stock looking icon pack, and have app drawer, or slap a launcher on it, some aspects of the phone are just too heavily themed. Like how they slaughtered the material design floating action button. But the performance is really faultless in my time with it. If I wanted a bigger screen phone, this would definitely be in my consideration. Where I live Huawei provides a more competitive warranty package too.
S7 Edge would be my choice here, because it's just such a well rounded package for the most part. Camera and display is right at the top of the pack along with IP68. The software design is actually pretty decent too even on the Nougat beta. But, it's too far along in its cycle to me to get one now for me. Especially with the next generation of flagship phones on their way.
Design wise I find both just as good looking, so again, it's preference.
But frankly if you're not someone who changes phone frequently, then it doesn't matter anyway. Just weigh what you like and dislike about each phone, and then see what you can live with, and what you can't live without.
The fact that this is a decision should tell u something.

Long time Samsung user here -- I've got an S7 Edge, but I just picked up a Mate 9 this afternoon. Been playing with it for a few hours.
My situation is pretty simple: I want a big screen, but I ABSOLUTELY DETEST the Samsung "edge." And Samsung seems to be devoted to it, at least with phones available in the US. So, I thought I'd give the Mate 9 a shot.
I'm happy that I could swap the buttons around to proper Samsung order, and I'll try to live without wireless charging. That's the really big loss for me. Not that I've researched if there are any wireless charging cover options for the Mate 9 yet -- though I looked for Mate 9 cases on Amazon, and nothing like that popped up there.
So far, things are mostly going OK -- my main beefs so far are about the lock screen, which I just want to do away with completely, and just go to the home screen when I wake the phone. So far, I haven't figured out how to get rid of the ultra-annoying "magazine" message, and having to swipe to get to the home screen. I just don't see any options that say "turn that stuff off."
Otherwise, I'm pretty impressed with the Mate 9. I'm very happy with the screen and the sound, though it's a bit too early to talk about much else at this point. Oh, and I guess I goofed up on that "factory-installed screen protector" -- I figured that was the kind of protection stuff that you take off of new electronics, so I yanked that off right at the beginning. Oh, well.
At any rate, for me, it's either the Mate 9 winning the job over the S7 Edge, or it goes back to Best Buy.

I just managed to get my favorite home and lock screen background installed -- just a basic, medium-to-dark solid blue color. Did I say I was happy with the Mate 9's screen? Oh, my! It's nothing about resolution or clarity or anything like that, but rather brightness and contrast -- the S7 Edge's screen is absolutely luscious, whereas the Mate 9's screen looks utterly washed out and lifeless. I'm now hitting the Play Store to see if there's anything that'll let me adjust the contrast, as that's badly, badly needed!

I would not go back to the S7 Edge. I have the S7 edge on JUMP ON DEMAND so I'll definitely try the S8+ when it comes out but I'm very happy with the Mate 9.

I wanted to keep the Mate 9 but T-Mobile doesn't have very good coverage in rural areas, so I returned it and went back to my blue coral S7 edge on Verizon.
Too bad the Mate 9 doesn't work on Verizon.

I'm really getting soured on the Mate 9 already. I am THIS CLOSE to boxing it back up and returning it. I would actually be doing that, but I've got a case coming, and I'll give that a shot before I pull the plug. I'm hoping (with very little expectation for a positive outcome) that the case might work like the Samsung flip cases that it resembles -- and when you open the cover, you get straight to the home screen, without further wiping or using fingerprint ID or anything. Here are some other things I have noticed:
Man, the screen is just SO much worse than the G7Edge screen. And again, it's not about "resolution" at all -- it's about contrast, viewing angles, and all that. It just looks very "washed out" in almost every situation I'd use it. It's not really something I notice when viewing pictures or videos -- which my initial thoughts were based upon -- but rather, by just using the phone, looking at normal text and such. The G7Edge screen is just in an entire different universe. Yes, the Samsung OLED screen is absolutely amazing.
The other thing I've noticed is how the Mate 9 "buttons" -- the home, back, and open apps buttons -- TAKE UP SCREEN SPACE, whereas they are BELOW THE SCREEN on the G7Edge. And in effect, the screen of the Mate 9 is NO TALLER AT ALL than the G7Edge screen. That wouldn't be the case for "pictures" and "videos," but for apps, there just isn't more screen space with the Mate 9. The Mate 9 does give you a wider screen, so there's room for a bit more text there, but call the extra screen real estate kind of "one-dimensional." In the end, there just isn't enough extra screen space to make the larger phone worth it.
So, that's where I am now. I've switched my SIM card and my MicroSD card back over to the G7Edge, and the Mate 9 will sit there until the case comes. And I rather expect that within about five minutes, I'll be packing the Mate 9 up and heading back to Best Buy.

simple really. if you prefer a big BIG phone(screen) as I do go Mate 9. side by side the Edge looks like a toy. if 5x5 screen works go Edge.

title: Mate 9 is not Dual SIM Full Active. Lost that disguising feature from the rest of the competitors.

thread.text:
Mate 9 is dual SIM dual standby. 
Buy a mate 8 if you want DSFA feature. Huawei sold us all by making that phones stand by.
I already send them complains in facebook you can do the same.
I hope on mate 10 this feature to come back other ways it will lose us as their customers as all other flagship are also dual SIM standby. For that DSFA feature a great numbers of buyers was stack with Huawei.
Send by Huawei Mate 8 - NXT-L29 (The last DSFA in market) via Tapatalk.

replies.text: And the issue is ?????

Dual SIM active phones come with two transceivers, and are capable of receiving calls on both SIM cards or using data from one SIM and simultaneously talking from the second SIM.
Dual SIM standby phones allows both SIMs to be accessed through*time multiplexing. When making or receiving calls, the modem locks to the active channel; the other channel would be ignored and thus unavailable during the duration of the call. That means when someone is calling you on SIM 1 the SIM 2 is offline like switching the phone down, or when talking on one SIM you can not use data from the other SIM.
There is a major percentage of Huawei customers just for this feature.

title: Is Geek Squad Insurance Worth it for the Mate 9

thread.text:
I just purchased Geek Squad insurance for the Mate 9.
My main concern with the Mate 9 is because it's not a very well known brand yet here in the US, not sure how easy or hard it will be to get it serviced if the screen breaks or something else goes wrong.
The insurance cost me $149 and I will pay $149 for each claim I submit. I still have time to get a full refund if I change my mind.
a good drop protection case with a tempered screen protector and just being careful with it is all the insurance you will need. Total cost - about $20.
Mobile phone insurance is typically at a higher cost. I would check the squaretrade plan. It might be slightly cheaper.

So for just about $300 dollars (the $149 upfront charge and the $149 deductible) you can replace a $600 phone - assuming your problem is a total loss? Doesn't sound like too good of a deal to me. I'd just spend $20 for a good screen protector and case and be cautious (as mentioned above).
I don't remember the last time I got insurance on my phone. But it depends on how you care for your phone. Screen protector + heavy duty case can go a long way
I got to agree with you... That insurance plan isn't worth it.

Ouch! That is ridiculously expensive insurance on this phone! Jeepentj makes the point - that's $300 to repair a $600 phone that will quickly be worth less than that. 
I bought a SquareTrade plan using one of their frequent discount offers for $66 for one year. There is a $99 fee if I make a claim. It doesn't cover loss or theft but I doubt the Geek Squad does either. I think the regular price for a SquareTrade one year plan is $89.
I never get more than a year because I know if I break my phone after a year... oops! Have to get a new phone! 
I just dug one of their emails out of my trash. Use code "FEB20" to get 20% off this week.
And another promo code just popped up when I was looking at their website: PHONE20

So you guys convinced me, I will cancel my insurance with Bestbuy.. might take a look at the Square Trade with the 20% discount... just received my UAG case and the phone looks pretty bad***, now to find a good tempered glass.

Is your Sync toggle on the phone on? If it's disabled it won't 'push' automatically.

Yup, the toggle should be in the notification shade, but if it's not there, you can also go to Settings, Accounts, and make sure that AutoSync is not turned off. 
As for counters, the app dev is correct. Not all launchers support unread counters (not sure about Huawei's), not all apps are supported, and some, like Nova, require separate plugins for those to work at all.

thread.text:
So I did a full FDR to try an fix my issue with not being able to run a few apps.(which fixed my Marriott app not being able to be installed or run!)
Now, for the life of me, cannot find the setting to get rid of the pop up that says disconnected from power. I didn't get that before the FDR. I thought I had read this in one of the forum threads but can't seem to find it. Anyone? Google has not been my friend on this one.

Happened to me with pop up msg when unplugged from power. Only for me doing standard reset got rid of it. 
I thought it odd. Others weren't seeing it so I realized was not a universal bug. 
Thought in my case a bad OS or because I first set it up without a sim card. 
I was going to wait it out until an update to N. Didn't want to go through all the work. When I reset I set it up as new, avoiding restoring anything.

replies.text: Thanks and very odd that this started to happen AFTER I did a full reset and a new non restored phone. I really didnt want to role the dice with another device reset just to see if this goes away. I may reach out to support to see what they say.

thread.text: That is very strange, I have never seen such msg. I have the Mate 9 on the first week it was available at BB. Not that I want the msg on mine, just curious why is this happening?
I get it every time and I never did a FDR. It's annoying. You have to clear it before you can do anything else. I don't see any setting for it.

--- See UPDATE 2 below in this post if you want this fixed!---
I get the exact same thing too. After a couple days of searching settings, I am going to try a full device wipe today. 
Very annoying.
--- Update 1 ---
Full device wipe fixed it. Thank God.
A couple of notes on this: 1) I did it from the recovery menu (power off, hold power button and volume up -- not from within system settings) 2) I setup the phone as a new phone and did not restore any settings from either google backup or Huawei backup.
--- Update 2 --- 
Gradually started reinstalling apps 1 by 1 and the pop up reappeared. The culprit in my case was LastPass, and specifically when I turned on Accessibility Service Access for application auto-fill. 
In short turning on Accessibility for for any application enables this pop-up. 
If you want to fix this go into Settings -> Advanced settings -> Accessibility, and make sure that under Services, all applications are switched to OFF.
Very odd, but glad to have this solved.
Thank you Brandon!!!! I actually spoke to Huawei support and they had no idea other than another FDR or replace the phone. 1Pass has the same issue for me.

replies.text: No problem, happy to help out. Hopefully Huawei fixes this soon.

thread.text: Wow - That's awesome troubleshooting! Unfortunately for me, I don't want to give up that functionality from LastPass.

title: Why did Huawei develop Mate 9 PRO?

thread.text:
After using the Mate 9 for a month I wonder why they offered the PRO. 
Screen -- Mate 9 is great
Speed -- my mate 9 is as fast as I need
Battery -- great
Storage -- 64gb plus SD is more than I need.
What do you think???

I think the Pro is for those who want a smaller sized model & have a high standard as far as screen display (1440p vs 1080p). But in defense of the Mate 9, among 1080p displays, it's excellent. Also you're eyes won't know the difference (1080p vs 1440p) unless you like to have your smartphones unreasonably close to your face lol. 
You're also getting a better screen to body ratio w/ the Mate 9 compared to the Pro version, meaning more screen in comparison to the overall size of the phone. 
If you like your phones the size of the Mate 9 (the iphone plus & Nexus 6p are also the same size but w/ a smaller screen), which I do also, it's the best Note 7 replacement imho (some may make an argument for the V20, but why pay a couple hundred more for the V20?) 
Inevitably I agree w/ you though & imho think you have nothing to worry about & made a great choice

I got the Mate 9 Pro because Daydream compatibility. If the Mate 9 had it, I would have stuck with it. But I am now regretting getting the Pro because it appears to be hard to get updates outside the region the phone was originally intended for.

What I have learned is only buy what the phone works with and what carriers offer those that support for the
bands
For VR, it's a Daydream ready phone and has a 1440P display. I agree the screen on the regular Mate 9 is more than sufficient and superb for everything else though.

thread.text:
I have been using the Mate 9 for about 10 days and wanted to post my thoughts. I tried to wait a few days because I often like a phone a lot while setting it up, only to find faults after using the phone a few days. I have used about every one of the top phones on the market (iPhone 7+, Pixel XL, S7 Edge, 6P, LG G5 and V20, HTC 10, Moto Z, One+3, Axon 7, etc.) and this is the best phone on the market right now, in my opinion. It has the best combination of size, screen, software, battery life and camera. 
Screen quality is always very important to me and I returned a number of phones because I could not stand the screen (LG I am looking at you). I was concerned about the 1080p, relatively low pixel density LCD screen, particularly considering the big 5.9 inch screen. In fact, I initially dismissed the thought of getting the Mate 9 for that reason. However, the screen is great. I can put it up next to the Pixel XL and look at the exact same things (pictures on 500 px, games, various apps) and rarely do I notice the difference between it and the AMOLED screen. It is much better than the smaller 1080p screens on the 7+, One+3, etc. I don't know how Huawei did it, but the screen is impressive considering the specs. 
The battery is awesome. The software with Nougat flies. It has a much larger screen in the same size body as the iPhone 7+ and the Pixel XL. Connectivity has been good (bluetooth works better than the Pixel). It works well on AT&T -- of course HD Voice is not available. I have not taken many pictures yet, so I cannot really comment on the camera. 
I have a hard time finding fault with this phone. Hopefully, Huawei will support it and issue quick security and other (7.1.1) updates.

I'd really like to see more picture samples from this phone. It looks like I'd really like it, but that is a huge thing for me. I have a OP3T right now and the camera in non-perfect light definitely leaves something to be desired. It's otherwise a great phone.

watches and phones will be the cause of my divorce.. hahaha.. found a craigslist ad for a mate 9 for $500.. debating if i should jump on that.. 
good taste on the grand seiko and the prospex.. re-issue of the prospex samurai is looking really good..

replies.text: Just make sure it isn't fake.

thread.text: For a phone it seemed excellent, if you want perfection I'd say get a camera.

I wanted to add a couple things to my comments above. First, this phone flies! It is the fastest phone I have used. I put it next to my Pixel XL and the Mate 9 is faster at everything it does. The UI is fast, but even the amount of time it takes from boot-up to syncing and downloading emails is amazingly fast. I use BB Hub and on every other phone it takes quite a while to download emails after the phone first starts up, but on the M 9 it is instantaneous. Email notifications are immediate. The quickness in downloading and installing updates from the Google Store is also amazing. There will be an occasional hiccup, just like I have experienced with every other Android phone, but it generally just flies. 
I like to switch between my 4 phones because I get bored (and i have the grass is greener syndrome), but I have a hard time using any of the others since I got the M9. I popped the SIM back in my S7 Edge and even with Nougat sideloaded on it, it is a serious dog compared to the M9. I cannot stand how slow it is at everything. It is hard to justify using the 7+ and XL with their smaller screens on bodies that are essentially the same size (only slightly narrower). The M9 screen blows away the iPhone screen and I really tried to compare the screens of the XL and M9 and had a hard time finding instances where the XL was noticeably better. 
Considering that the M9 is significantly less expensive than those other phones, it is impressive. I still have the reservations I mentioned above (security and updates), but it is a very good phone.

replies.text: What are your thoughts on the camera? Have you taken any pics of moving objects? I'm really interested in this phone. I have a OP3T right now and the camera lets me down - it's far worse than my over year old 6s Plus - and the screen is just "meh". I'm looking at ditching the OP3T for this, since it really isn't that much more, but I'd like to see some more picture samples.
I'm also going from the 3t to the mate 9. If the camera is even slightly better, I'll be happy

There are many reasons. One of coarse camera, which again I'm hoping for slightly better. The screen size to body ratio is unmatched. I believe the screen quality will be the same if not better. The ir blaster is just so convenient in a pinch...i had one in my honor 8. I like some of the customizations from what I've seen. 
The Oneplus is a great phone but It HAS had some quirks like the home screens having a little stutters, especially in shelf. The setting slide down stutters. I've had a bit of freezing and have had to reboot. I just think huawei is a more reputable company. Oneplus with 6gb ram and the top specs should have absolutely no issues. Unfortunately it still does.

I actually sold my OP3T yesterday. Still trying to decide on this phone. I have a Pixel (the small one) on order too. I've got it narrowed down to that, Honor 8 or Mate 9. I think the Mate would actually be my choice for now. I think it has the best combo of everything.

I've had both of those phones. The pixel I had twice and returned them for Bluetooth issues that never seem to get fixed. I think people are saying there is finally an update for it though. The honor 8 is a great phone and definitely the most cost effective. I really didn't have any issues with it but it was definitely not as smooth as the pixel or 3t. Oh, and the video camera is pretty horrible. I'd say it comes down to the size that suits you. Funny story but we are hosting 2 Chinese exchange students and one has the mate 8 which is bigger than the mate 9 and I find it still OK.

Well I need a good camera/video camera. We have a 14 year old, a 4 year old, and two month old twins. So I gotta save those memories. I've been using a 6s Plus for over a year. So the size wouldn't be a problem since they're basically the same size. I've just grown tired of Apple and keep looking at coming back to Android, which is basically all I used for about 5 years. But I need that all in one device that has all of the bases covered (quality, battery, camera, smoothness). And to be at a decent price doesn't hurt ($600 US isn't too bad for me, compared to the price of Pixels and iPhones).

Wow you got your hands full! I have three boys 15-14 and 8 so I know the feeling. My mate 9 should be here Tuesday and my criteria is about the same. We shall see. If I hold on to it more than 2 months my wife will be a happy camper. Lol hope to use it for a year if it works out!

thread.text: I have not taken any pictures yet that test the camera. I will try to take some and report back. I like good photography, but am not much of a photographer myself. I leave that to my wife. The reviews I have seen are pretty good for the M9 camera, but I really can't comment. Sorry.

replies.text: I find the camera(after a day of initial testing ) to be adequate but not great. The shutter is fast, the experience is fast, but comparing to my V20 it's not quite as good, especially in low light.

What version of sw are you on ? Posting about camera performance without the sw version isn't helpful. Mine just upgraded to B138 and i can say that the camera is one of the best that I've ever used, including samsung phones. 
Fred
I'm running B138 as well. I'm not saying it's a bad camera, it's just not the best, especially at lowlight conditions from my comparisons to the V20. I also have a OP3 and Nexus up for comparison.

I love this phone to death and cameras on phones are very important to me. So I have to admit that the lowlight performance in the Mate 9 is subpar compared to the 6P. I have decided to keep it because that is the only thing wrong with the phone other than the headphone jack in the top. I have other phones for low light so I'm not as concerned. The camera otherwise is great. 
Tips that I have found to improve the camera. Because I am a Samsung and 6P user and like the more saturated photos that they take. I found that you can dial up the standard saturation in the Mate camera in the camera settings under image adjustment settings. Move the saturation from default to up to +1 and things get better. If you like more muted colors leave it alone. 
Lastly, view your mate 9 photos on a super AMOLED display and you will also notice a difference in how they look. Not for lowlight though.
awesome feedback about the default saturation setting! I didn't see that before!

replies.text:
Inaccurate in what sense ?
Fred

"Before we list the Mate 9’s positive traits, let’s discuss its biggest blemish: the 5.9-inch display. Yes, it gets very bright and has excellent black levels for an IPS panel, but Huawei’s display calibration leaves a lot to be desired. The overly cool white point, imperfect gamma, and wide gamut support lead to poor grayscale and color accuracy. Huawei does include preconfigured Cold and Warm white point settings, but they only make things worse. The screen looks decent after adjusting the white point manually, but it still trails other flagship phones. Huawei also misses an opportunity to provide better color accuracy by not providing an sRGB display mode, although, some people will like the punchy colors from its wide gamut display. Viewing angles are not particularly good either."http://www.anandtech.com/show/10871/...te-9-review/10

I have to mostly agree with this statement. The screen is very much acceptable but it's not great at the same time. I tend to like to curl up in my bed after work and put some nice headphones on and watch TV shows and movies from my phone. I've done this with many phones but the big seller here was a bigger screen. There has been moments where sometimes I miss the colors and contrast from an AMOLED screen.
I really wish this was a well calibrated AMOLED screen
Lcd is fine... The screen on my iPhone 7 Plus is pretty accurate.
Thats a little subjective. I really prefer deeper blacks

There's nothing subjective about it. The iPhone 7 Plus is a very accurate display, and there mate 9 is not. As to what you prefer... That's up to you. Some people prefer an inaccurate display.
Also, Black levels on the iPhone 7 Plus is good too.

thread.text:
So a bit of a weird one, and maybe not a typical use case for most people. But, I have a Google Wifi mesh setup, and it generally works OK. However, the Mate 9 seems to have significantly degraded connection when switching between mesh points. It still shows up with full network connectivity, but everything internet related runs very slow. If I turn wifi on/off it picks up again, but only until I move around again to another room within a different mesh point coverage. Doesn't happen to any other devices.
Anyone seen something similar either with Google Wifi or other bridged wifi network setups?
I haven't seen any issues with my google mesh wifi setup.

replies.text: OK, thanks. I was trying to avoid a factory reset, but it may end up that way.

thread.text: I don't have Google wifi setup, but I am using Ubiquiti wifi setup. I don't see any issue yet. You probably at the borderline between the handoff to the next closest access point where signal is not low enough to drop. I wouldn't say it is an issue and I don't think it has anything to do with Mate 9. It is the access point decision to drop you off from one and hand off to the next best. Yes, you will have to move around to trigger that event. I think, this is true from any mesh network.

replies.text: Your comment makes sense, except I don't have the issue with any other devices. I figured it's a bit on the fringe side of issue, but i'm glad to hear others don't experience it. I'll keep monitoring and see if things change.

Perhaps, the Mate 9 is doing such a good job with the signal that makes the access point thinks it didn't need to hand off yet. While the other devices dropped below the threshold sooner and AP handed off to the next closest AP. With that said, this could be the Mate 9 is doing such a good job that actually is bad for the wireless performance in your situation.
Ah, didn't think of that. The M9 does otherwise and in all other places have great signal.

title: There are THREE charging speeds - did I miss that info somewhere?

thread.text:
I just discovered there are THREE charging speeds on this phone: standard, fast and supercharge
I found this out because I bought this little Honor kit for $9 hoping I might get a supercharger out of it (the price has since doubled!). Turns out it's a Huawei charger but it only "fast charges" the Mate 9 according to the home screen. Actually has a really nice selfie-stick if you are into that.https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/...?ie=UTF8&psc=1

I did a very informal and unscientific test of the fast charging mode. I went from 72% to 86% in 13 min. As I understand, it slows down as it approaches full which I think it did around 90%. This was informal, did not check amperage or anything,
Did I miss this information about the three charging modes?

Doing this, I can go around two or two and a half days without having to charge it.

title: Only found one Desktop/Tablet/Phone SMS app that works: Pulse SMS

thread.text:
I have tried Pushbullet, Join, mySMS, and MightyText (my longtime favorite) and none of them provided consistent or even functioning texting from your desktop or tablet. I tried them with my favorite, Textra, Google Messenger and the stock SMS app. Something with the Mate 9 prevents all of these from using it for desktop and/or tablet texting.
I did find one solution that works: Pulse SMS
Pulse SMS has a website, a Chrome extension and its app. It keeps all your texts on the web and in the app on other devices. I have it installed on my tablet and it shows all of my message histories. Very convenient. 
You have to use the app as your texting app. It's not a bad app. I still think Textra has a bit of an edge but Pulse has many of the same features. It comes from the same developer who did EvolveSMS and Talon. I'm getting adjusted to using Pulse as my texting app and it's growing on me.
Pulse is a paid app but I think it's reasonably priced. You get a 7 day trial.
I am not affiliated with the developer. Just sharing my experience so if you are looking to text from your computer and/or tablet on the Mate 9, this is the way to go.
So this is basically iMessage but for Android? How does it send texts from a PC/Tablet - does it require your phone to be on or does it send them via the Internet?

replies.text:
No, not exactly. iMessage does not have a desktop interface for texting. The iPad version only lets you send messages to other iPhone users from the iPad. It doesn't let you send regular SMS messages which is necessary if you want to send texts to anyone that doesn't use an iPhone.
These Android service use your Gmail account to get the messages to your phone and the phone to send/receive the texts. The phone does the actual sending and receiving. If your phone is off, it won't work.
SMS is a very old system but I still use it. Services like WhatsApp are cross-platform and can be used on many devices. They use data channels to send/receive messages (WiFi, mobili data).

thread.text: You can use HiSuite to send messages from the PC too...

But we are all being watched...And listened to...And databased. So ultimately just decide what trade off you're willing to make for tech.
